question_text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening fatigue and recurrent bleeding from his gums for 2 weeks. Physical examination shows marked pallor. There are scattered red, nonblanching pinpoint spots on his trunk and extremities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 8.0 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 80,000/mm^3, and a platelet count of 104,000/mm^3. Genetic analysis of a bone marrow aspirate shows leukemic cells with a balanced translocation between the long arms of chromosome 15 and 17. These cells are most likely to stain positive for which of the following?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening fatigue and recurrent bleeding from his gums for 2 weeks. Physical examination shows marked pallor. There are scattered red, nonblanching pinpoint spots on his trunk and extremities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 8.0 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 80,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 104,000/mm3. Genetic analysis of a bone marrow aspirate shows leukemic cells with a balanced translocation between the long arms of chromosome 15 and 17. These cells are most likely to stain positive for which of the following?
hint: A peripheral blood will likely show Auer rods in this patient's circulating myeloid cells, which are particularly associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia, a form of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
learning_objective: Recognize acute promyelocytic leukemia, and recall its associated cytochemical stain.

answers.explanation_why: The presence of myeloperoxidase (MPO) in leukemic cells of a bone marrow aspirate confirms that the cells are of myeloid lineage, and thus differentiates acute myeloid leukemia (AML) from MPO-negative acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). This patient's age, clinical presentation, lab values, and t(15;17) translocation indicate AML, which is why the cells of his bone marrow aspirate will likely stain positive for MPO. Another characteristic feature of AML is Auer rods, which are particularly associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia. Acute promyelocytic leukemia can be treated with vitamin A derivates such as ATRA (all-trans-retinoic acid).

images.title: Acute promyelocytic leukemia
images.description: Photomicrographs of a peripheral blood smear (H&E stain; very high magnification)The large basophilic cells are promyelocytes, identifiable by their eccentric nuclei and abundant basophilic cytoplasm containing numerous Auer rods (rod-like intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies). This type of hypergranular leukemic promyelocyte is often still referred to as a “faggot cell” for the resemblance of accumulation of Auer rods to a “bundle of sticks,” although the term is typically avoided today due to its derogatory associations.The presence of promyelocytes containing Auer rods in a peripheral blood smear is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia.Note: Basophilic remnants (Howell-Jolly bodies) are visible within most of the erythrocytes, indicating (in this case) increased hematopoiesis.

answers.explanation_why: Expression of tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is increased in lymphocytes of patients with hairy cell leukemia. This type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma presents with symptomatic anemia and thrombocytopenia as seen in this patient. However, affected individuals usually develop massive splenomegaly as well as leukopenia. Moreover, t(15;17) translocation is not associated with hairy cell leukemia, which is instead characterized by the eponymous hairy cells in peripheral blood smear.

images.title: Hairy cell leukemia
images.description: Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (May-Grunwald Giemsa stain; very high magnification)Multiple atypical lymphocytes (examples indicated by blue circles) can be seen among numerous normal erythrocytes (examples indicated by white arrowheads) in the center of the image. The cell membrane of these lymphocytes feature fine, hair-like cytoplasmic projections (examples indicated by black arrowheads) and enlarged nuclei with slightly irregular borders (examples indicated by dashed line). A binuclear cell is also present (arrow).The presence of atypical lymphocytes with hair-like cytoplasmic projections in a peripheral blood smear indicates hairy cell leukemia. The diagnosis was confirmed on immunophenotyping.

answers.explanation_why: Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) staining identifies polysaccharides, which can be helpful for diagnosing many diseases, including glycogen storage diseases and Whipple disease. Moreover, erythroid precursor cells in acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) can stain positive for PAS. While some of this patient's findings could be attributed to ALL, his age, t(15;17) translocation, and absence of lymphadenopathy is more indicative of AML.

Cluster of differentiation 1a is a protein expressed by Langerhans cells that mediates the presentation of antigens to T cells. Unregulated proliferation of Langerhans cells leads to Langerhans cell histiocytosis, which typically manifests in childhood with lytic bone lesions (most commonly in the skull), skin rash, fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. It is not associated with this patient's t(15;17) translocation.

Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is a marker for immature lymphocytes because its gene is exclusively transcribed by lymphoblasts during their early phases of maturation. The presence of TdT in leukemic cells of a bone marrow aspirate confirms that the cells are of lymphoid lineage and thus differentiates acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) from AML. While some of this patient's findings could also be attributed to ALL, his age, t(15;17) translocation, and absence of lymphadenopathy is more indicative of AML.

images.title: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
images.description: Photomicrograph of bone marrow smear (H&E stain)Multiple lymphoblasts, identifiable as large basophilic cells with abundant granular cytoplasm and a large round nucleus with clumpy chromatin and prominent nucleoli, can be seen. The presence of > 20% of lymphoblasts within a bone marrow smear is diagnostic of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The cells surrounding the lymphoblasts are erythroid precursors, mature erythrocytes, and mature neutrophils.Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

question_text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of intermittent watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. He has had a 12-kg (26-lb) weight loss during this period. He has also had episodic pain of the ankle, wrist, and knee joints during the past 5 years. An endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is performed. Histopathologic examination of a tissue specimen shows foamy macrophages in the lamina propria with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive inclusions. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of intermittent watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. He has had a 12-kg (26-lb) weight loss during this period. He has also had episodic pain of the ankle, wrist, and knee joints during the past 5 years. An endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is performed. Histopathologic examination of a tissue specimen shows foamy macrophages in the lamina propria with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive inclusions. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Chronic polyarthritis that precedes the development of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss raises suspicion for Whipple disease. Small bowel biopsy showing PAS-positive, foamy macrophages in the lamina propria confirms the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize Whipple disease, and recall its diagnostic histopathological finding.

answers.explanation_why: Multinucleated trophozoites would be found in the stool sample of a patient with severe diarrhea of protozoan etiology (e.g., Entamoeba histolytica or Giardia lamblia). Although this patient presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and diarrhea, the presence of PAS-positive foamy macrophages is highly indicative of another infection not caused by protozoan species.

Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (most common), anti-endomysial antibodies, and anti-deamidated gliadin peptide antibodies are all serological markers seen in celiac disease. This patient's weight loss, diarrhea, and abdominal pain are concerning for a pathology involving the small bowel. Histological findings in celiac disease would, however, include villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytic infiltration. This patient's biopsy shows PAS-positive foamy macrophages, which is not consistent with celiac disease, but rather, is the histological hallmark of a specific infectious condition.

images.title: Celiac disease etiopathogenesis
images.description: The ingestion of gliadin, a component of gluten, leads to an immune response in the intestinal epithelium in individuals with celiac disease. Gliadin is deamidated by tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and then ingested by antigen-presenting cells (APC), which activate T cells via MHC II receptors. The activated T cell then activates plasma cells to release anti-tTG, anti-endomysial, and anti-deamidated gliadin antibodies (which all function as diagnostic markers of celiac disease). T cells also differentiate into TH1 cells, which activate cytoplasmic fibroblasts to release matrix proteases. This leads to the destruction of the intestinal architecture with villus atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and the loss of the brush border.

answers.explanation_why: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies (ACPA) are serological markers used in the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis. The presence of long-standing arthralgia would be consistent with this diagnosis, but this patient's recurrent diarrhea, weight loss, abdominal pain, and small bowel biopsy findings are not. These findings are more indicative of an infectious pathology of the small bowel.

Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA) are serological markers that help distinguish between Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis, as they are more prevalent in the former. Although patients with inflammatory bowel diseases may present with some of the extraintestinal manifestations (e.g., arthralgia) seen in this patient, these disorders also cause chronic, bloody diarrhea. Additionally, the presence of PAS-positive inclusions in this patient's biopsy is highly indicative of a specific infectious pathology.

The causative organism in Whipple disease is Tropheryma whipplei, an intracellular, gram-positive bacillus. Frequently missed in staining, the histological hallmark of classical Whipple disease is periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) reactive vacuoles in macrophages found within the lamina propria of the small bowel, as seen in this patient. Whipple disease is lethal if left untreated. Intravenous ceftriaxone for 14 days is the recommended induction therapy for Whipple disease, followed by maintenance therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) for 1 year.

images.title: Whipple disease
images.description: Photomicrograph of duodenal tissue (H&E stain)There are goblet cells (colorless cells; examples indicated by green overlays) within the columnar epithelial cells and immune cells (examples indicated by black arrowheads) within the lamina propria. There are numerous macrophages (single and in loose aggregates) within the lamina propria, causing blunting of the villi.These findings are characteristic of Whipple disease.

answers.content: Low serum TSH and high free T4 concentrations
answers.explanation_why: Low serum TSH and high free T4 concentrations would be suggestive of hyperthyroidism. Weight loss and diarrhea are clinical features of hyperthyroidism, but this patient's abdominal pains, joint pains, and PAS-positive foamy macrophages on biopsy are hallmarks of an infectious pathology of the small bowel.

question_text: A previously healthy 36-year-old man comes to the physician for a yellow discoloration of his skin and dark-colored urine for 2 weeks. He does not drink any alcohol. Physical examination shows jaundice. Abdominal and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. Serum studies show increased levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST). A liver biopsy is performed and a photomicrograph after periodic acid-Schiff-staining is shown. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
content_preview: A previously healthy 36-year-old man comes to the physician for a yellow discoloration of his skin and dark-colored urine for 2 weeks. He does not drink any alcohol. Physical examination shows jaundice. Abdominal and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. Serum studies show increased levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST). A liver biopsy is performed and a photomicrograph after periodic acid-Schiff-staining is shown. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
hint: This patient's elevated transaminases and signs of hyperbilirubinemia (jaundice, darkened urine) indicate liver damage. His biopsy findings of PAS-positive, spherical, inclusion bodies in hepatocytes confirm α1-antitrypsin deficiency (AAT deficiency) as the most likely underlying cause.
learning_objective: Recognize α1-antitrypsin deficiency, and recall its pulmonary complications.

answers.explanation_why: Tropheryma whipplei-specific RNA on PCR is diagnostic for Whipple disease, an intestinal disorder caused by infection with the bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. Whipple disease typically manifests as a malabsorptive syndrome with abdominal pain, extraintestinal symptoms (e.g., arthritis, fever, polyserositis), and PAS-positive macrophages on intestinal biopsy. However, signs of hepatic damage and PAS-positive inclusion bodies as seen in this patient would not be expected.

images.title: Whipple disease
images.description: Photomicrograph of duodenal tissue (H&E stain)There are goblet cells (colorless cells; examples indicated by green overlays) within the columnar epithelial cells and immune cells (examples indicated by black arrowheads) within the lamina propria. There are numerous macrophages (single and in loose aggregates) within the lamina propria, causing blunting of the villi.These findings are characteristic of Whipple disease.

answers.content: Bullous changes of the lung bases on chest CT
answers.explanation_why: Bullous changes of the lung bases on chest CT scan is a typical finding of emphysema, a sequela of AAT deficiency. AAT deficiency is an autosomal codominant disorder associated with liver damage and panacinar emphysema secondary to the proteolytic destruction of alveolar architecture by the enzyme elastase. Hepatic accumulation of AAT presents as PAS-positive, spherical, inclusion bodies on liver biopsy.

answers.content: Beading of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts on ERCP
answers.explanation_why: Beading of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts on ERCP is a diagnostic feature of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). PSC typically presents in middle-aged men with early signs of cholestasis (e.g., jaundice, pruritus, fatigue) and liver damage as seen in this patient. However, "onion skin" scarring and fibrosis of bile ducts on liver biopsy, rather than PAS-positive inclusion bodies, would be expected. In addition, PSC is usually associated with other autoimmune diseases, especially ulcerative colitis (UC). This patient shows no signs of UC such as bloody stool or abdominal pain.

answers.content: Myocardial iron deposition on cardiovascular MRI
answers.explanation_why: Myocardial iron deposition on cardiovascular MRI is found in hemochromatosis. Hemochromatosis is mostly asymptomatic but usually becomes symptomatic between the third and fifth decades of life, with a classic triad of cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, and skin pigmentation. Although hemochromatosis presents with liver damage, the biopsy findings are characterized by positive Prussian blue staining and pronounced iron deposits in hepatocytes rather than PAS-positive inclusion bodies as seen in this patient. In addition, other symptoms such as arthritis, pituitary infiltration, and cardiomyopathy would be expected.

answers.content: Dark corneal ring on slit-lamp examination
answers.explanation_why: Dark corneal ring on slit-lamp examination (Kayser-Fleischer ring) results from the accumulation of copper in the Descemet membrane of the cornea and is found in ∼ 98% of patients affected by Wilson disease. Although Wilson disease causes hepatic damage, a liver biopsy would show positive copper staining and hepatic copper concentration > 250 μg/g instead of PAS-positive inclusion bodies as seen in this patient. In addition to hepatic and ocular involvement, a broad spectrum of neurologic and psychiatric manifestations would also be expected in Wilson disease.

images.title: Kayser-Fleischer ring
images.description: Slit-lamp photography of a left eyeA brown ring is visible in the periphery of the cornea (Kayser-Fleischer ring; green overlay).Kayser-Fleischer rings are typically seen in Wilson disease.

images.title: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (liver)
images.description: Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (PAS diastase stain; approx. 450x magnification)PAS-positive and diastase-resistant globular cytoplasmic inclusions (green overlay) can be seen within periportal hepatocytes. The periportal fibrous tissue has been highlighted for orientation (white overlay).These are the characteristic histopathological findings in alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. Additional immunohistochemical staining should be performed to confirm that the inclusions contain alpha-1 antitrypsin.

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of recurrent thumb pain that worsens with exposure to cold temperatures. Examination shows a 6-mm, blue-red papule under the left thumbnail. The overlying area is extremely tender to palpation. The thumbnail is slightly pitted and cracked. This lesion most likely developed from which of the following types of cells?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of recurrent thumb pain that worsens with exposure to cold temperatures. Examination shows a 6-mm, blue-red papule under the left thumbnail. The overlying area is extremely tender to palpation. The thumbnail is slightly pitted and cracked. This lesion most likely developed from which of the following types of cells?
hint: This patient's tender blue-red lesion under the left thumbnail, with pain that worsens with exposure to cold temperatures, suggests a glomus tumor.
learning_objective: Recognize a glomus tumor, and recall its cell of origin.

answers.explanation_why: Dysplastic melanocytes are characteristic of a dysplastic nevus or melanoma. These lesions can uncommonly develop under the nail (e.g., acral lentiginous melanoma) but are not typically painful or sensitive to cold temperatures.

images.title: Atypical nevus
images.description: An asymmetric, pigmented lesion with irregular borders and color variegation is visible over the left little finger.These are characteristic features of an atypical nevus.

answers.explanation_why: Hemangiomas are comprised of capillary endothelial cells. Cherry hemangiomas in adults commonly develop on the trunk and upper extremities as multiple, painless, cherry-red, dome-shaped papules; they are not typically found under the nail.
answers.explanation_but: Infantile hemangiomas are also comprised of capillary endothelial cells and may manifest as blue-red papules on the fingers. They are typically not painful and usually involute within a few years.

images.title: Capillary hemangioma of the skin (cherry angioma)
images.description: Multiple well-demarcated cherry-red papules are distributed on the skin.This appearance is characteristic of cherry angiomas.

answers.explanation_why:
Glomus tumors are benign tumors that arise from modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus body, which is involved in dermal thermoregulation. These tumors classically manifest as small (< 2 cm), solitary, painful, blue-red papules or nodules located on the hand, foot, or under the nails in patients 20–40 years of age. The pain associated with glomus tumors is characteristically paroxysmal, severe, and is exacerbated by cold.

Diagnosis is typically clinical and confirmed by histopathologic examination. Treatment involves surgical excision.

images.title: Glomus tumor
images.description: A solitary vascularized subcutaneous nodule is visible on the pulp of the little finger of the left hand.

answers.explanation_why: Hyperpigmented fibroblasts are characteristic of a dermatofibroma, which typically manifests as an asymptomatic, brown papule on the lower extremities with characteristic central dimpling when pinched (dimple sign); they are not typically found under the nail.

images.title: Dermatofibroma
images.description: A solitary, pigmented, firm circular lesion is visible. Upon pinching of the lesion, the overlaying skin retracts inwards (dimple sign).This appearance is suggestive of a dermatofibroma, which usually manifests as a nodule.

answers.explanation_why: Abnormal growth of basal epidermal cells can cause basal cell carcinomas (BCC), which can uncommonly manifest as a pigmented lesion. However, BCCs typically develop in older individuals with an extensive history of sun exposure as a nodular, nontender lesion with a rolled border and central ulceration. BCCs are not typically found under the nail and they are not associated with cold sensitivity.

images.title: Pigmented basal cell carcinoma
images.description: A red-brown plaque with nodules is visible on an area of skin from the patient's upper thigh. The lesion exhibits both irregular (left) and well-defined borders (right). The surface of the lesion is shiny. Brown melanin pigmentation can also be seen.

question_text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because he is worried about a mole on his right forearm. He has had the mole for several years, but it has grown in size in the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a hyperpigmented plaque with irregular borders and small area of ulceration. Histopathologic analysis of a full-thickness excisional biopsy confirms the diagnosis of malignant melanoma. Invasion of which of the following layers of skin carries the highest risk of mortality for this patient?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because he is worried about a mole on his right forearm. He has had the mole for several years, but it has grown in size in the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a hyperpigmented plaque with irregular borders and small area of ulceration. Histopathologic analysis of a full-thickness excisional biopsy confirms the diagnosis of malignant melanoma. Invasion of which of the following layers of skin carries the highest risk of mortality for this patient?
hint: Tumor thickness is one of the most important prognostic factors for malignant melanoma.
learning_objective: Recall the prognostic significance of skin layer invasion in malignant melanoma.

answers.explanation_why: Malignant cells in the stratum corneum are contained within the epidermis. Tumors confined to this layer are classified as a malignant melanoma in situ (MMIS) and are unlikely to metastasize, as there is no lymphovascular supply within the epidermis. The mortality rate for patients diagnosed with MMIS is low.

Malignant cells extending into the reticular dermis have a high potential for metastatic spread, as the dermis contains blood and lymph vessels. However, invasion of a different layer of skin carries an even higher risk of mortality.

Malignant cells extending into the papillary dermis have metastatic potential, as the dermis contains blood and lymph vessels. However, it is not the deepest layer of the skin and invasion of a different layer of skin carries an even higher risk of mortality.

The hypodermis (subcutis) is the deepest layer of the skin, and melanoma mortality is directly correlated with tumor thickness. Due to variability in the thickness of skin compartments among different individuals, tumor thickness does not always correspond with skin layer invasion. However, in this patient, it is likely that a tumor extending into the hypodermis is thicker than a tumor in a more superficial layer. Breslow depth is an important prognostic factor used for melanoma staging and to determine the safety margin of a wide local excision.

images.title: Layers of the skin
images.description:
The skin is composed of the cutis (epidermis and dermis) and the subcutis.- The epidermis has five layers: stratum corneum, lucidum, granulosum, spinosum, and basale.
- The dermis has two layers: papillary and reticular dermis.
- The subcutis contains fat and neurovascular structures.

answers.explanation_why: Malignant cells in the stratum basale are contained within the epidermis. Tumors confined to the stratum basale are classified as a malignant melanoma in situ (MMIS) and are unlikely to metastasize, as there is no lymphovascular supply within the epidermis. The mortality rate for patients diagnosed with MMIS is low.

question_text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and abdominal pain. Physical examination shows pale mucous membranes and splenomegaly. Hemoglobin concentration is 9.1 g/dL and leukocyte count is 3,400/mm^3. Peripheral blood smear shows nucleated red blood cells and teardrop poikilocytosis. A Janus kinase 2 gene mutation is present. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and abdominal pain. Physical examination shows pale mucous membranes and splenomegaly. Hemoglobin concentration is 9.1 g/dL and leukocyte count is 3,400/mm3. Peripheral blood smear shows nucleated red blood cells and teardrop poikilocytosis. A Janus kinase 2 gene mutation is present. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?
hint: The combination of anemia, leukopenia, splenomegaly, and teardrop cells in a 65-year-old patient with a JAK2 gene mutation indicates impaired hematopoiesis due to a condition associated with increased fibroblast activity.
learning_objective: Recognize primary myelofibrosis, and recall its associated genetic mutation.

answers.explanation_why: Viral replication in B lymphocytes is seen in infectious mononucleosis (IM) caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Splenomegaly is a common finding in IM and aplastic anemia is a rare but serious complication of this disease. However, peripheral smear in IM will show atypical lymphocytes rather than teardrop poikilocytosis as seen in this patient. Additionally, IM has no association with a JAK2 gene mutation.

images.title: Atypical lymphocytosis in infectious mononucleosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; very high magnification)Multiple atypical lymphocytes (1) are visible. Atypical lymphocytes are activated T cells with a polymorphic nucleus and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. Inactive lymphocytes (2) are comparatively smaller with a round nucleus and thin cytoplasm rim. Despite being activated T cells, atypical lymphocytes strongly resemble monocytes (3), hence the name infectious mononucleosis.

answers.explanation_why: In hairy cell leukemia, clonal B lymphocytes infiltrate the reticuloendothelial system and interfere with bone marrow function, causing marrow fibrosis with dry tap and pancytopenia. Splenomegaly is common in this disease due to extramedullary hematopoiesis. However, peripheral smear in hairy cell leukemia will show “hairy” cells rather than teardrop poikilocytosis seen in this patient. In addition, there is no association with a JAK2 gene mutation.

images.title: Hairy cell leukemia
images.description: Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (May-Grunwald Giemsa stain; very high magnification)Multiple atypical lymphocytes (examples indicated by blue circles) can be seen among numerous normal erythrocytes (examples indicated by white arrowheads) in the center of the image. The cell membrane of these lymphocytes feature fine, hair-like cytoplasmic projections (examples indicated by black arrowheads) and enlarged nuclei with slightly irregular borders (examples indicated by dashed line). A binuclear cell is also present (arrow).The presence of atypical lymphocytes with hair-like cytoplasmic projections in a peripheral blood smear indicates hairy cell leukemia. The diagnosis was confirmed on immunophenotyping.

answers.explanation_why:
Bone marrow fibrosis is the end result of primary myelofibrosis, a disorder characterized by increased fibroblast activity and connective tissue deposition in the bone marrow; it is positive for a JAK2 gene mutation in about 50% of cases. Teardrop cells seen on peripheral blood smear reflect altered bone marrow architecture, which causes red blood cells to become deformed as they leave the marrow to enter the circulation. Splenomegaly is also common in primary myelofibrosis due to extramedullary hematopoiesis in the spleen. A 'dry tap' on bone marrow biopsy would be expected due to extensive medullary fibrosis.

A JAK-2 gene mutation is also associated with other myeloproliferative neoplasms, including polycythemia vera and essential thrombocythemia.

The Philadelphia chromosome, a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, leads to the development of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). CML often presents with abdominal discomfort due to splenomegaly and anemia, both of which are seen in this patient. However, CML is more likely to cause leukocytosis than leukopenia and is not associated with teardrop poikilocytosis or a JAK2 gene mutation.

Hepcidin is responsible for intracellular sequestration of iron and can cause anemia of chronic disease. Elevated hepcidin levels could explain this patient's anemia, but they would not cause leukopenia, splenomegaly, or a mutated JAK2 gene. Moreover, this patient has no history of chronic disease.

question_text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a rash on the elbows for several months. A biopsy of the affected area shows a thinned stratum granulosum as well as retained nuclei and spongiotic clusters of neutrophils in the stratum corneum. This patient's skin findings are most likely associated with which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a rash on the elbows for several months. A biopsy of the affected area shows a thinned stratum granulosum as well as retained nuclei and spongiotic clusters of neutrophils in the stratum corneum. This patient's skin findings are most likely associated with which of the following conditions?
hint: Thinning of the stratum granulosum, parakeratotic stratum corneum (retained nuclei), and clusters of neutrophils in the stratum corneum (Munro microabscesses) on this patient's skin biopsy are highly suggestive of psoriasis.
learning_objective: Recognize psoriasis, and recall its associated conditions.

answers.explanation_why: Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy seen in up to ⅓ of patients with psoriasis. Apart from skin involvement, common findings in psoriatic arthritis include asymmetric arthritis, nail lesions, inflamed, sausage-like fingers (dactylitis), and pencil-in-cup deformity of the distal interphalangeal joints (DIPs) on x-ray.

Gliadin hypersensitivity is not associated with psoriasis but is characteristic of celiac disease, which is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis, an autoimmune blistering skin disorder. Unlike this patient's findings, skin biopsy in dermatitis herpetiformis shows subepidermal clefting and blistering with IgA deposition at dermal papillae.

Hepatitis C virus infection is not associated with psoriasis but is characteristic of lichen planus, a skin condition that can also manifest on the elbows. However, skin biopsy in lichen planus shows hypergranulosis rather than this patient's thinning of the stratum granulosum.

Hashimoto thyroiditis does not occur at higher rates in patients with psoriasis but is associated with other autoimmune conditions, including vitiligo. Vitiligo is characterized by depigmentation of the skin caused by destruction or dysfunction of melanocytes, which is inconsistent with this patient's findings.

Parkinson disease is not associated with psoriasis but does often occur in patients with seborrheic dermatitis. This inflammatory skin condition causes recurring itchy and/or burning flares that show erythematous, patchy scaling, or greasy yellow crust on examination, unlike this patient's presentation.

Insulin resistance (e.g., diabetes or Cushing syndrome) is not associated with psoriasis but is characteristic of acanthosis nigricans. However, acanthosis nigricans does not typically manifest on the elbows. Additionally, skin biopsy in acanthosis nigricans shows acanthosis.
answers.explanation_but: Acanthosis nigricans is commonly due to an underlying malignancy (especially gastric cancer).

question_text: A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of pruritic blister formation. Physical examination shows multiple 1–3 cm bullae on the palms, soles, lower legs, and inguinal folds. Gentle rubbing of the skin does not result in sloughing of the epidermis. Immunofluorescence studies of a perilesional skin biopsy specimen are most likely to show deposition of antibodies in which of the following areas?
content_preview: A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of pruritic blister formation. Physical examination shows multiple 1–3 cm bullae on the palms, soles, lower legs, and inguinal folds. Gentle rubbing of the skin does not result in sloughing of the epidermis. Immunofluorescence studies of a perilesional skin biopsy specimen are most likely to show deposition of antibodies in which of the following areas?
hint: The patient presents with large, pruritic bullae on the palms, soles, lower legs, and inguinal folds, sparing the mouth. Nikolsky sign is negative. These clinical features are typical of bullous pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disease, most common in older adults.
learning_objective: Recognize bullous pemphigoid, and recall its immunofluorescence findings.

answers.explanation_why:
Direct immunofluorescence in bullous pemphigoid reveals linear deposition of IgG and C3 at the dermo-epidermal junction. The bullae are formed due to an immune reaction caused by autoantibodies directed against bullous pemphigoid antigen 1 and bullous pemphigoid antigen 2 (components of the hemidesmosome). Microscopic examination of a blistering lesion usually reveals the presence of eosinophils with the separation of tissue layers subepidermally causing tense bullae.

Bullous pemphigoid is a benign disease that usually responds well to treatment with high-dose topical steroids.

images.title: Bullous pemphigoid
images.description: A: Microscopy (100x magnification) with immunofluorescence using IgG and C3 autoantibodies showing deposition along the basement membrane of a skin tissue sample.B: Microscopy (200x magnification) with indirect immunofluorescence using IgG and C3 autoantibodies showing deposition along the epidermal junction of a skin tissue sample.

answers.explanation_why: Deposition of antibodies between epidermal keratinocytes is seen in pemphigus vulgaris, characterized by acantholysis that results in the formation of intraepidermal blisters and bullae. Acantholysis is induced by IgG antibodies directed against desmoglein 3 and desmoglein 1, which usually mediate keratinocyte adherence. Blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are flaccid and nonpruritic rather than tense and pruritic as seen here. Moreover, lesions typically first present on the oral mucosa and the Nikolsky sign is positive.

images.title: Pemphigus vulgaris
images.description: Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

answers.explanation_why: No staining on direct immunofluorescence is observed in Stevens Johnson syndrome as the pathogenesis is thought to be a T-cell mediated type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which does not involve antibody antigen interaction. Although bullae are present in this disease, other skin features include extensive, full-thickness epidermal necrosis and sloughing (resembling large superficial burns) and mucosal involvement along with a positive Nikolsky sign.

images.title: Toxic epidermal necrolysis (severe Stevens-Johnson syndrome)
images.description: Right arm of an infant in whom toxic epidermal necrolysis was likely triggered by smallpox vaccination

answers.explanation_why: Granular deposits of IgA in the dermal papillae are observed in dermatitis herpetiformis with antibodies directed against epidermal transglutaminase. Although dermatitis herpetiformis presents with pruritic blisters, they are usually in grouped (herpetiform) arrangement and the most commonly involved sites include elbows, dorsal forearms, knees, scalp, back, and buttocks. Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with celiac disease.

images.title: Dermatitis herpetiformis
images.description: Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

answers.explanation_why: Perivascular immunoglobulin deposition is seen in porphyria cutanea tarda. Although it presents with bullae and blisters, they are a manifestation of chronic photosensitivity. Moreover, other skin features including increased scarring, hypertrichosis, and hyperpigmentation affecting sun-exposed areas of the body, are absent here. Lastly, porphyria cutanea tarda mainly occurs in older men with chronic alcoholism and hepatic cirrhosis.

images.title: Porphyria cutanea tarda
images.description: A fluid-filled blister is visible on the index finger. Deep ulcers and superficial erosions can be seen on the back of the left hand.These features are consistent with porphyria cutanea tarda.

question_text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, flank pain, and hematuria. He has chronic back pain, for which he has been taking meloxicam for the past 2 weeks. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F). Physical examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash over his trunk and extremities. Urinalysis shows 10–15 RBC/hpf, 20 WBC/hpf, and numerous eosinophils. Microscopic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, flank pain, and hematuria. He has chronic back pain, for which he has been taking meloxicam for the past 2 weeks. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F). Physical examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash over his trunk and extremities. Urinalysis shows 10–15 RBC/hpf, 20 WBC/hpf, and numerous eosinophils. Microscopic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient's presentation (2-day fever, flank pain, maculopapular rash) and urine abnormalities (hematuria, sterile pyuria, eosinophiluria) are consistent with a hypersensitivity reaction, most likely due to his NSAID intake (meloxicam).
learning_objective: Recognize allergic interstitial nephritis, and recall its histopathological findings.

answers.explanation_why: Tubular crystal precipitation is seen in crystal-induced AKI. It is caused by low-solubility drugs (e.g., acyclovir, indinavir, ciprofloxacin, methotrexate) that precipitate in the renal tubule, causing obstruction of normal urine flow and damage to renal tubular cells. Although asymptomatic in most patients, crystal-induced AKI can sometimes manifest with flank pain and acute onset of hematuria, as seen here. However, this patient's meloxicam use (not a low-solubility drug), eosinophiluria, and rash are inconsistent with crystal-induced AKI.

Deposition of IgA in the mesangium is consistent with IgA nephropathy. Clinical features include hematuria, pyuria, flank pain, and low-grade fever, as seen in this patient. However, IgA nephropathy is most commonly preceded by a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. In addition, IgA nephropathy is not associated with a maculopapular rash or eosinophiluria.

images.title: IgA nephropathy
images.description: Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

answers.explanation_why: Glomerular crescent formation is a feature of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), which can present with acute onset of hematuria, pyuria, and flank pain, as seen in this patient. However, it is also associated with anuria, edema, and acanthocytes and RBC casts on urinalysis. In addition, RPGN is inconsistent with this patient's maculopapular rash or eosinophiluria.

images.title: Crescent formation in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN)
images.description: Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

answers.explanation_why: Tubular cells with clear cytoplasm are seen in clear cell carcinoma, the most common type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC can also present with fever, painless hematuria, and flank pain. However, RCC is inconsistent with the maculopapular rash, pyuria, and eosinophiluria seen in this patient. Furthermore, this patient lacks additional characteristic findings of RCC, such as hypertension, weight loss, fatigue, night sweats, and a palpable abdominal mass.

images.title: Clear cell renal cell carcinoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)Countless nests of polygonal cells (examples indicated by green overlays) with clear cytoplasm, filled with lipids and glycogen, are visible (examples indicated by yellow overlays). The tissue is richly vascularized (examples of blood vessels indicated by arrowheads).This is the typical histopathological appearance of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

answers.explanation_why: Diffuse interstitial T-cell and monocyte infiltration is seen in allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN), a hypersensitivity reaction that can occur days to weeks after the initiation of NSAIDs, such as meloxicam. Drugs that act as haptens (e.g., NSAIDs, antibiotics) have the ability to elicit an uncontrolled immune response and acute kidney injury.

Renal papillary necrosis is characteristic of analgesic nephropathy (e.g., prolonged use of NSAIDs and/or acetaminophen). Although analgesic nephropathy can also present with hematuria and flank pain, it is usually due to chronic analgesic use. This patient's maculopapular rash and eosinophiluria are inconsistent with papillary necrosis.
answers.explanation_but: Other causes of renal papillary necrosis include sickle cell disease, pyelonephritis, and diabetes mellitus.

answers.explanation_why: Cortical and medullary cyst formation is seen in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). It results from a mutation in the PKD-1 gene, on chromosome 16, which encodes for polycystin. This patient's age, flank pain (caused by cyst rupture or UTI), and pyuria raise concern for ADPKD. However, ADPKD is associated with chronic renal failure, hypertension, and recurrent urinary tract infections. In addition, ADPKD is inconsistent with this patient's maculopapular rash or eosinophiluria.

question_text: A 51-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of shortness of breath, fever, and chills. He has no history of serious illness. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F). Physical examination shows a grade 4/6, holosystolic, blowing murmur over the apex that radiates to the axilla. Crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. Examination of the extremities shows several nontender, nonblanching, erythematous macules on the palms and soles. Histopathologic examination of these macules is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 51-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of shortness of breath, fever, and chills. He has no history of serious illness. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F). Physical examination shows a grade 4/6, holosystolic, blowing murmur over the apex that radiates to the axilla. Crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. Examination of the extremities shows several nontender, nonblanching, erythematous macules on the palms and soles. Histopathologic examination of these macules is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with high fever, dyspnea, and a mitral regurgitation murmur, which suggests acute infective endocarditis of the mitral valve, complicated by pulmonary edema. The nontender, erythematous macules on the palms and soles of this man are most likely Janeway lesions.
learning_objective: Recognize acute infective endocarditis, and recall the histopathology of Janeway lesions.

answers.content: Capillary wall rupture with fibrin thrombus formation
answers.explanation_why: Roth spots are the fundoscopic finding of white-centered retinal hemorrhages that are characterized histologically by microthrombi that form at the site of retinal capillary damage. They can be seen with infective endocarditis, as well as with leukemia, anoxic brain injury, carbon monoxide poisoning, and HIV. In contrast, Janeway lesions do not affect the eye and hemorrhage is not believed to be a primary component of Janeway lesions.

images.title: Roth spots
images.description: Fundus photography of a left eyeThere are multiple red, white-centered lesions, which reflect small retinal hemorrhages with central accumulation of leukocytes or fibrin thrombocyte emboli (examples indicated by arrowheads).Although these findings were formerly considered to be associated almost exclusively with infective endocarditis, they may actually occur in a variety of conditions, including hypertensive, diabetic, and HIV-related retinopathy; leukemia; and intracranial hemorrhage.Circle: optic disc; M= macula

answers.content: Microabscesses with neutrophil infiltration of capillaries
answers.explanation_why: Microabscesses with neutrophil infiltration of capillaries and areas of hemorrhage are characteristic of the Janeway lesions seen in patients with infective endocarditis. They are thought to be caused by septic microemboli from valve vegetations and, among other vascular phenomena, constitute a minor clinical criterion for the Duke criteria in infective endocarditis. Janeway lesions are more common in acute endocarditis than in subacute endocarditis.

answers.content: Epithelioid cells with surrounding multinucleated giant cells
answers.explanation_why: Epitheloid cells with surrounding multinucleated giant cells are characteristic of granulomatous inflammation, which is associated with numerous conditions, including tuberculosis, systemic fungal infection, sarcoidosis, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis. However, none of these conditions present with high fever and a new-onset heart murmur. Janeway lesions are not caused by granulomatous inflammation.

Cleft-like vacuoles within arterioles are the histological hallmark of cholesterol embolism. The most common skin manifestations of cholesterol embolization include livedo reticularis, gangrene, cyanosis, skin ulcer, purpura or petechiae, and firm, painful erythematous nodules. Janeway lesions have a different appearance on histology than cholesterol emboli.
answers.explanation_but: The vacuole appearance of cholesterol embolism occurs due to cholesterol dissolution when exposed to tissue fixation.

images.title: Renal cholesterol emboli
images.description: Photomicrograph of renal tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)Spindle-shaped, white spaces (yellow overlay) can be seen in an arterial vessel (dashed outline). These spaces (cholesterol clefts) are formed when the fat molecules in cholesterol emboli dissolve during sample processing.

answers.content: Spiral-shaped bacteria with axial filaments in the epidermis
answers.explanation_why: Spiral-shaped bacteria with axial filaments on microscopic examination of a specimen would be consistent with secondary syphilis, which is caused by an infection with the spirochete Treponema pallidum. Patients with secondary syphilis present with a disseminated, maculopapular rash involving the entire trunk and extremities (including the palms and soles). However, this patient does not have any other clinical features of secondary syphilis, such as generalized lymphadenopathy, myalgia, or condylomata lata.

question_text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. Pulmonary examination shows bibasilar inspiratory crackles. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple nodular opacities in the upper lobes and calcified hilar nodules. Pulmonary functions tests show an FEV1:FVC ratio of 80% and a severely decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide. A biopsy specimen of a lung nodule shows weakly birefringent needles surrounded by concentric layers of hyalinized collagen. The patient has most likely been exposed to which of the following?
content_preview: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. Pulmonary examination shows bibasilar inspiratory crackles. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple nodular opacities in the upper lobes and calcified hilar nodules. Pulmonary functions tests show an FEV1:FVC ratio of 80% and a severely decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide. A biopsy specimen of a lung nodule shows weakly birefringent needles surrounded by concentric layers of hyalinized collagen. The patient has most likely been exposed to which of the following?
hint: The patient's worsening dyspnea, cough, and decreased DLCO raise suspicion for an interstitial lung disease. The biopsy findings, together with the upper lobe nodular opacities and calcified hilar lymph nodes, are characteristic of exposure to a substance classically associated with hard rock mining.
learning_objective: Recognize chronic silicosis, and recall its associated occupational exposure.

answers.explanation_why: Berylliosis is typically seen in patients working in high-tech sectors, such as the nuclear and aerospace industries, where beryllium alloys are common. While berylliosis also affects the upper lobes and would present similarly to this patient, histological analysis is characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas and a reticular interstitial pattern on chest x-ray similar to that of sarcoidosis.

This patient is suffering from chronic silicosis due to an occupational exposure to crystalline silica, as evidenced by the pathognomic biopsy findings that are consistent with a silicotic nodule. Radiographic abnormalities, such as diffuse ground glass or nodular opacities, can arise early in the disease (typically the upper lobes). However, overt symptoms can take decades of exposure to develop, which is consistent with this patient's advanced age.

Advanced silicosis patients are at particularly high risk for developing tuberculosis.

images.title: Silicosis
images.description: Chest x-ray (PA view) of a man with occupational exposure to stone dust who presented with chronic dyspneaThere are multiple nodular opacities present, predominantly in the upper lobes of the lungs (examples indicated by arrowheads). The nodules have conglomerated to form irregular masses (green overlay). The diaphragmatic domes are abnormally elevated indicating fibrosis (indicated by lines and arrows), which is visible as linear opacities adjacent to the shadow of the base of the heart (yellow overlay). The mediastinum is widened, indicating hilar lymphadenopathy.Diffuse upper lobe nodules, fibrosis, and hilar lymphadenopathy are characteristic of silicosis.

answers.explanation_why: Exposure to thermophilic actinomyces spores in moldy hay can lead to a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, called Farmer's lung. This would also present with progressive dyspnea and chronic cough, but histology would instead reveal granulomatous inflammation with lymphocytes and polynuclear giant cells. Furthermore, chest x-ray would show ground-glass opacities with honeycombing, and in some cases, emphysema.

images.title: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
images.description: H&E stain: There is a circumscribed granuloma (green area) of lymphocytes and multinucleated giant cells (red areas) on the left below the bronchus (Br), which are a characteristic indication of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. (Alv = alveolus, B = blood vessel)

answers.explanation_why: Chronic exposure to carbon dust can result in Coal worker's pneumoconiosis. Similar to this patient's condition, black lung results in small nodular opacities on chest x-ray, specifically in the upper lung fields. Histologic analysis, however, would instead show deposition of dark pigment in the interstitial tissue and hilar lymph nodes due to carbon accumulation in alveolar macrophages.

Exposure to asbestos fibers can lead to development of asbestosis later in life. While asbestosis also presents indolently with dyspnea and a chronic cough, the chest x-ray typically shows lower lobe involvement and pathognomonic findings of supradiaphragmatic and pleural calcifications. Diagnosis is aided by identification of the golden, beaded appearance of asbestos fibers in sputum, which are coated with iron and ferritin (thus called ferruginous bodies) after being phagocytosed by macrophages.

question_text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of sharp, left-sided lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. Menarche occurred at 12 years of age, and menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses an intrauterine device for contraception. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows left lower quadrant tenderness and cervical motion tenderness. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Transvaginal ultrasound shows no intrauterine gestational sac. An endometrial biopsy is performed. Which of the following is the most likely finding?
content_preview: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of sharp, left-sided lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. Menarche occurred at 12 years of age, and menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses an intrauterine device for contraception. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows left lower quadrant tenderness and cervical motion tenderness. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Transvaginal ultrasound shows no intrauterine gestational sac. An endometrial biopsy is performed. Which of the following is the most likely finding?
hint: Unilateral pain, adnexal tenderness, and vaginal bleeding in a pregnant patient, together with the absence of an intrauterine pregnancy on transvaginal ultrasound, indicate an ectopic pregnancy.
learning_objective: Recognize ectopic pregnancy, and recall the expected endometrial biopsy findings.

answers.explanation_why:
Decidualized endometrium without chorionic villi is a classic endometrial biopsy finding in ectopic pregnancy, in which the embryo implants outside the uterine cavity, most commonly in the fallopian tube. Progesterone from the corpus luteum still acts on the endometrium, causing enlargement and secretory transformation of stromal cells (decidualization). Fetal structures (chorionic villi) are absent because the gestational sac is not in the uterus. 

Risk factors for ectopic pregnancy include prior ectopic pregnancy, pelvic inflammatory disease, tubal surgery, smoking, and advanced maternal age. Although intrauterine devices (IUDs) decrease the overall likelihood of pregnancy, individuals who do become pregnant with an IUD in situ are more likely to have an ectopic pregnancy than those without an IUD.

answers.content: Proliferative endometrium with no secretory changes
answers.explanation_why: A proliferative endometrium is seen in the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle before ovulation, when estrogen is the dominant hormone. In this pregnant patient, the endometrium would be secretory or decidualized due to progesterone.

answers.content: Diffuse hydropic villi and trophoblastic proliferation
answers.explanation_why: Diffuse hydropic villi and trophoblastic proliferation indicate a molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole). Although molar pregnancies can manifest with abnormal uterine bleeding and a positive urine pregnancy test, an ultrasound would show a snowstorm pattern or mass in the uterus, not an empty cavity.

images.title: Types of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD)
images.description: GTD is a group of diseases that originate in the placenta and typically result from abnormal fertilization of the ovum. Complete and partial moles may develop malignant traits and become invasive. Choriocarcinoma may be preceded by hydatidiform moles (50% of cases), ectopic pregnancy or miscarriages, or normal pregnancy. Theca lutein cysts result from exaggerated stimulation of the theca interna cells of the ovarian follicles due to excessive amounts of beta-hCG.

answers.explanation_why: Decidualized endometrium with chorionic villi indicates that a gestational sac is implanted within the uterine cavity, as seen in a normal intrauterine pregnancy or an intrauterine miscarriage. This patient does not have an intrauterine gestational sac on ultrasound.

answers.content: Glandular and stromal breakdown with neutrophils
answers.explanation_why: Glandular and stromal breakdown with neutrophils is a typical finding in acute endometritis, which can manifest with lower abdominal pain. However, this condition typically occurs following delivery or a procedural abortion. Acute endometritis also manifests with fever, chills, and uterine tenderness, none of which are present in this patient.

question_text: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of progressively worsening edema and decreased urine output over the past few days. He has a history of chronic sinus infections and was hospitalized last year for a suspected pneumonia with hemoptysis. Physical exam shows bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities. Serum studies show a creatinine of 3.4 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen of 35 mg/dL. Urine dipstick shows 3+ blood. A kidney biopsy is performed and light microscopy shows crescent-shaped glomeruli. Immunofluorescent microscopy of the tissue sample is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of progressively worsening edema and decreased urine output over the past few days. He has a history of chronic sinus infections and was hospitalized last year for a suspected pneumonia with hemoptysis. Physical exam shows bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities. Serum studies show a creatinine of 3.4 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen of 35 mg/dL. Urine dipstick shows 3+ blood. A kidney biopsy is performed and light microscopy shows crescent-shaped glomeruli. Immunofluorescent microscopy of the tissue sample is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient has a history of sinopulmonary disease and is now presenting with signs of nephritic syndrome (hematuria, edema, oliguria, elevated creatinine) due to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), as biopsy findings of crescent-shaped glomeruli confirm. This constellation of features indicates granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) as the most likely diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, and recall the immunofluorescent microscopy findings.

answers.explanation_why: Subendothelial deposits are seen in type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. MPGN is typically associated with autoimmune diseases such as SLE or chronic infections such as hepatitis C, though it can be idiopathic. While type I MPGN can cause RPGN, it is less likely in this patient because it does not have an association with sinopulmonary disease.

Deposits within the glomerular basement membrane are seen in type II membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, also known as dense deposit disease. MPGN is typically associated with autoimmune diseases such as SLE or chronic infections such as hepatitis C, though it can be idiopathic. While type II MPGN can cause RPGN, it is less likely in this patient because it does not have an association with sinopulmonary disease.

IgA nephropathy typically causes mesangial deposits, which are made up of IgA. IgA nephropathy can present with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, which this patient has, and can also be associated with a respiratory infection. However, IgA nephropathy typically follows an acute infection, such as a URI, and is not associated with chronic sinopulmonary disease. It also usually presents relatively early in life, most commonly between the ages of 10 and 30.

Subepithelial deposits are usually due to membranous nephropathy, a nephrotic syndrome. The patient's hematuria and rapid-onset oliguria suggest an RPGN rather than a nephrotic syndrome. In addition, membranous nephropathy is typically associated with chronic infections, especially hepatitis B or hepatitis C, lupus, or malignancy, none of which this patient has.

Type III RPGN is caused by small vessel vasculitides, such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and is pauci-immune, meaning that there is little to no immunofluorescent staining of deposits. The typical finding on light microscopy is a crescent-moon shape caused by extracapillary cell proliferation.

GPA typically affects patients in their 7^th or 8^th decades of life. Besides RPGN, complications of GPA include upper and lower respiratory tract involvement, skin lesions, ocular pathology, and cardiac pathology.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of unintentional weight gain of 5.5 kg (12.2 lb) and irregular menstrual cycles over the past 2 months. She does not take any medications. Her blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, hyperpigmentation of the palmar creases, and violaceous scarring of the abdomen. Early morning serum cortisol levels are elevated and serum adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is within the reference range after a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test. A high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows suppression of ACTH. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of unintentional weight gain of 5.5 kg (12.2 lb) and irregular menstrual cycles over the past 2 months. She does not take any medications. Her blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, hyperpigmentation of the palmar creases, and violaceous scarring of the abdomen. Early morning serum cortisol levels are elevated and serum adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is within the reference range after a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test. A high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows suppression of ACTH. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient has signs of Cushing syndrome: weight gain with central obesity, abdominal striae, hypertension, hyperpigmentation, and irregular menses. A positive low-dose dexamethasone suppression test indicates hypercortisolism. A serum ACTH within the reference range in this context is considered abnormal, as ACTH secretion should physiologically be suppressed by elevated serum cortisol levels. Suppression of ACTH with high-dose dexamethasone confirms increased ACTH production from the pituitary gland (Cushing disease).
learning_objective: Recognize Cushing disease, and recall the expected adrenal gland findings.

answers.explanation_why: Pituitary gland atrophy is observed in Sheehan syndrome, which presents with hypopituitarism. The earliest presenting symptom is failure to lactate after delivery due to impaired prolactin secretion, which can also be followed by sequential development of secondary hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, and adrenal insufficiency. Even though this patient has menstrual irregularity, she does not have clinical features of hypothyroidism or adrenal insufficiency, nor risk factors for Sheehan syndrome (e.g., recent pregnancy), and her serum ACTH level does not align with hypopituitarism.

answers.content: Benign adenoma of the adrenal medulla
answers.explanation_why: Benign adenoma of the adrenal medulla affects chromaffin cells, which are regulated by preganglionic sympathetic fibers. Pheochromocytoma is a chromaffin cell tumor that is mostly benign and affects the adrenal medulla in 90% of cases. Its clinical features include episodic hypertension, paroxysmal palpitation, headache, and pallor due to sympathetic hyperstimulation as a result of excess catecholamine secretion. This patient does not have any of these features.

answers.content: Nodular hypertrophy of the zona reticularis
answers.explanation_why: Patients with Cushing disease will have diffuse and bilateral zona reticularis hyperplasia (not hypertrophy) due to excessive ACTH-dependent adrenocortical stimulation.

answers.content: Bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata
answers.explanation_why: This patient with Cushing disease most likely has bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata due to excessive ACTH-dependent adrenocortical stimulation. In addition, excessive pituitary or ectopic ACTH production leads to development of hyperpigmentation in areas not normally exposed to the sun as seen in this patient's palmar crease. This results from increased collateral melanocyte stimulating hormone production, which is cleaved from the same precursor protein (proopiomelanocortin) as ACTH.

answers.content: Unilateral carcinoma of the adrenal cortex
answers.explanation_why: Excessive cortisol secreted by an adrenal cortex tumor can cause many clinical features of Cushing syndrome, such as this patient's weight gain with central obesity, abdominal striae, hypertension, and irregular menses. However, unlike ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome, adrenocortical cancer does not induce skin hyperpigmentation as there is no increased collateral melanocyte stimulating hormone secretion. Additionally, elevated cortisol would cause decreased ACTH levels (unlike in this patient), since cortisol suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis through a negative feedback loop.

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of cough and decreased urination. The cough was initially nonproductive, but in the last few days he has coughed up small amounts of blood-tinged sputum with clots. He has not had any fevers, chills, or weight loss. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. Pulse is 115/min and blood pressure is 125/66 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dried blood around the lips. Serum studies show a creatinine of 2.9 mg/dL. Results of a serum antineutrophil cytoplasm antibody test are negative. A biopsy specimen of the kidney is most likely to show which of the following light microscopy findings?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of cough and decreased urination. The cough was initially nonproductive, but in the last few days he has coughed up small amounts of blood-tinged sputum with clots. He has not had any fevers, chills, or weight loss. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. Pulse is 115/min and blood pressure is 125/66 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dried blood around the lips. Serum studies show a creatinine of 2.9 mg/dL. Results of a serum antineutrophil cytoplasm antibody test are negative. A biopsy specimen of the kidney is most likely to show which of the following light microscopy findings?
hint: Hemoptysis and rapidly deteriorating renal function are seen in Goodpasture syndrome, a type of pulmonary-renal syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Goodpasture syndrome, and recall its kidney biopsy findings.

answers.explanation_why: Neutrophilic infiltration of the capillaries with subendothelial deposits (e.g., wire looping of the capillaries) is often observed in diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis, the most common and severe subtype of lupus nephritis. SLE can present with pulmonary involvement including pneumonitis or interstitial lung disease. However, this patient lacks other classic features of SLE, such as myalgias, arthritis, fevers, fatigue, and malar rash.

Expansion of the mesangial matrix and mesangial deposits of IgA are the pathognomonic microscopy findings in IgA nephropathy. Patients with IgA nephropathy often present with gross hematuria and flank pain following an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. IgA nephropathy is not associated with pulmonary involvement, as seen in this patient.

images.title: IgA nephropathy
images.description: Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

answers.explanation_why: Thinning of the glomerular basement membrane is seen in Alport syndrome, which most commonly presents during infancy with gross hematuria and progresses during adolescence to chronic kidney disease, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities. The combination of renal and pulmonary symptoms in this patient and his lack of visual and hearing problems suggest a different condition.

images.title: Alport syndrome
images.description: Electron micrograph of a kidney biopsy sample.The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) demonstrates an irregular thickness, with splitting and a basket-weave appearance (black arrow).These findings are consistent with Alport syndrome.

answers.explanation_why:
In Goodpasture syndrome, a subtype of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, deposition of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies causes damage to the glomerular capillary wall, which allows plasma products such as fibrinogen and inflammatory mediators to escape from the glomerulus. This is characterized by crescent moon-shaped, fibrin-containing deposits within the Bowman capsule seen on light microscopy. Patients classically present with nephritic syndrome, oliguria or anuria, fatigue, and hemoptysis.

Immunofluorescence microscopy from a renal biopsy in Goodpasture syndrome would show linear deposition of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane.

images.title: Crescent formation in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN)
images.description: Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

answers.explanation_why: Enlarged and hypercellular glomeruli can be observed on light microscopy in acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). PSGN typically manifests with tea-colored urine, periorbital edema, and hypertension following group A streptococcal infections, particularly pharyngitis. It most often affects children between the ages of 3–12 years and adults above the age of 60 years. This patient does not have any history or physical findings suggestive of PSGN.

images.title: Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
images.description: Microscopic image of a kidney biopsy (PAS stain, high magnification)A renal corpuscle surrounded by numerous tubules can be seen in the center of the image. Because the renal corpuscle is markedly enlarged, the space between the glomerular capillaries and the parietal layer of the Bowman capsule (black dashed outline) is narrowed. Within the glomerulus, there is hypercellularity due to proliferation of endothelial cells (yellow arrowheads) and mesangial cells (black arrowheads). Inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly neutrophils (blue arrowheads) and monocytes (white arrowheads), is also present. As a result, the lumina of the capillaries are not clearly identifiable.This is the histopathologic appearance of postinfectious glomerulonephritis.

question_text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of nausea and chronic abdominal pain that is worse after eating. She has Hashimoto thyroiditis. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. A biopsy specimen of the corpus of the stomach shows destruction of the upper glandular layer of the gastric mucosa and G-cell hyperplasia. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of nausea and chronic abdominal pain that is worse after eating. She has Hashimoto thyroiditis. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. A biopsy specimen of the corpus of the stomach shows destruction of the upper glandular layer of the gastric mucosa and G-cell hyperplasia. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following conditions?
hint: The patient has chronic indigestion and gastric biopsy has revealed corporal parietal cell destruction (upper glandular layer). In a patient with a history of autoimmune disease (Hashimoto thyroiditis), this constellation of findings is consistent with autoimmune atrophic gastritis.
learning_objective: Recognize autoimmune atrophic gastritis, and recall its associated cancer risks.

answers.explanation_why: Autoimmune metaplastic atrophic gastritis (AMAG) can lead to intestinal metaplasia, which increases the risk of gastric adenocarcinoma. Patients with AMAG are also at increased risk for carcinoid tumors because of the presence of autoantibodies against parietal cells, which normally produce gastric acid. The resulting achlorhydria stimulates the release of gastrin and antral G-cell hyperplasia, resulting in hypergastrinemia. Hypergastrinemia, in turn, is associated with enterochromaffin-like cell hyperplasia, which may progress to gastric carcinoid tumor.

Duodenal perforation is a complication of environmental atrophic gastritis, which is due to increased production of gastric acids in H. pylori infection and resulting mucosal inflammation and thinning. The autoimmune destruction of parietal cells in autoimmune atrophic gastritis results in achlorhydria, which is not associated with an increased risk of duodenal perforation.

A Curling ulcer is a stress ulcer that occurs in patients with recent severe burn injuries and could manifest with nausea and abdominal pain, which are seen in this patient. However, symptoms would be acute rather than chronic. Curling ulcers also have a tendency to perforate, which would result in severe pain and peritonitis due to perforation. Lastly, in the case of a Curling ulcer, there would be damage extending through the muscularis mucosa, which is not consistent with this patient's biopsy findings.

Aplastic anemia is a type of normocytic anemia that is caused by bone marrow failure. Autoimmune atrophic gastritis is characterized by the presence of autoantibodies against parietal cells, which usually produce intrinsic factor. A deficiency of intrinsic factor can result in vitamin B_12 malabsorption in the terminal ileum, causing macrocytic pernicious anemia.

The risk of gastric MALT lymphoma, a B-cell lymphoma, is increased in patients with environmental atrophic gastritis that is secondary to H. pylori infection. However, gastric MALT lymphoma is not associated with autoimmune atrophic gastritis.
