question_text: A 59-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of progressive abdominal swelling and shortness of breath for 1 week. He drinks 12–13 alcoholic beverages daily. He appears emaciated. Examination shows pallor, jaundice, hepatomegaly, gynecomastia, and a protuberant abdomen with a fluid wave and shifting dullness. Ultrasonography of the liver shows a solitary lesion with irregular borders. Which of the following tumor markers is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
content_preview: A 59-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of progressive abdominal swelling and shortness of breath for 1 week. He drinks 12–13 alcoholic beverages daily. He appears emaciated. Examination shows pallor, jaundice, hepatomegaly, gynecomastia, and a protuberant abdomen with a fluid wave and shifting dullness. Ultrasonography of the liver shows a solitary lesion with irregular borders. Which of the following tumor markers is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
hint: This patient has features of alcohol-associated cirrhosis (pallor, jaundice, hepatomegaly, gynecomastia, ascites, history of alcohol use disorder), and his ultrasound findings suggest hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
learning_objective: Recognize alcohol-associated cirrhosis, and choose the most appropriate tumor marker for monitoring.

answers.explanation_why: Chromogranin A is a serum tumor marker for neuroendocrine neoplasms (e.g., carcinoid tumors, small cell lung carcinoma). HCC, which this patient most likely has, is not a neuroendocrine tumor and is not associated with elevated chromogranin A levels.

Desmin is a muscle-specific, immunohistochemical tumor marker that can be used to screen for skeletal muscle tumors (e.g., rhabdomyosarcoma). HCC, which this patient most likely has, is not associated with elevated desmin levels.

S-100 protein is an immunohistochemical tumor marker for tumors derived from neural crest cells (e.g., melanoma). HCC, which this patient most likely has, is not derived from neural crest cells and is therefore not associated with elevated S-100 protein levels.

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) can be used as a tumor marker for some germ cell tumors (e.g., yolk sac tumor) and liver tumors. AFP is typically elevated in patients with HCC and may be used both for initial diagnosis and treatment monitoring. 

AFP may be used in combination with abdominal ultrasound for HCC screening in patients with cirrhosis.
Cancer antigen 125 is a tumor marker for ovarian cancer.
Cancer antigen 15-3 (along with cancer antigen 27-29) is a tumor marker for breast cancer.
Carcinoembryonic antigen is a nonspecific tumor marker for colorectal cancer and pancreatic cancer.
Carcinoembryonic antigen is a nonspecific tumor marker for pancreatic cancer and gastric cancer.
Beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (ß hCG) is a tumor marker for choriocarcinomas and germ cell tumors.

question_text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive difficulty swallowing and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. He first had trouble swallowing solid foods and then also developed difficulty swallowing liquids over the past week. Endoscopy shows a large mass 3 cm proximal to the esophagogastric junction. Biopsy of the mass shows significant distortion of glandular architecture. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive difficulty swallowing and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. He first had trouble swallowing solid foods and then also developed difficulty swallowing liquids over the past week. Endoscopy shows a large mass 3 cm proximal to the esophagogastric junction. Biopsy of the mass shows significant distortion of glandular architecture. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
hint: Visualization of a mass in the distal third of the esophagus with histopathologic examination that shows distorted glandular architecture confirms a diagnosis of esophageal adenocarcinoma.
learning_objective: Recognize esophageal adenocarcinoma, and recall its risk factors.

answers.explanation_why: Atrophic gastritis increases the risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (eSCC). Bacterial overgrowth in the achlorhydric stomach generates reactive carcinogenic nitrogen products that can induce eSCC transformation. Although eSCC manifests with dysphagia and weight loss, as seen in this patient, a biopsy would show pathognomonic circular areas of keratinization. Atrophic gastritis is not associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Chronic consumption of hot liquids and food increases the risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (eSCC) due to thermal damage of the esophageal mucosa. The resulting inflammation stimulates the production of reactive nitrogen species, which are carcinogenic. Although eSCC manifests with dysphagia and weight loss, as seen in this patient, a biopsy would show pathognomonic circular areas of keratinization. Consumption of hot liquids is not associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Chronic and excessive alcohol consumption increases the risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (eSCC). Although eSCC manifests with dysphagia and weight loss, as seen in this patient, biopsy findings would show pathognomonic circular areas of keratinization. While chronic alcohol use can cause gastroesophageal reflux disease, alcohol consumption has not been associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma. Moreover, another predisposing factor is more strongly associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Obesity is an important risk factor for esophageal adenocarcinoma. Although the exact mechanism is unknown, it is hypothesized that obesity increases the risk of adenocarcinoma by increasing the risk of reflux and via mechanisms independent of reflux. Gastroesophageal reflux disease induces metaplasia (Barrett esophagus), which can progress to adenocarcinoma. In addition, excessive visceral fat increases the risk of inflammation, the production of cytokines and growth factors, and insulin resistance, all of which are risk factors for carcinoma. Other risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma include smoking, achalasia, and certain diets (high in animal protein or cholesterol, low in fiber). Smoking and achalasia furthermore increase the risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

Chronic consumption of nitrosamine-rich foods (e.g., bacon, other cured meats, pickles, alcohol) is associated with an increased risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (eSCC). Although eSCC manifests with dysphagia and weight loss, as seen in this patient, a biopsy would show pathognomonic circular areas of keratinization. Consumption of cured meats is not associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

question_text: An otherwise healthy 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of episodic abdominal cramps, bloating, and flatulence. The symptoms worsen when she has pizza or ice cream and have become more frequent over the past 4 months. Lactose intolerance is suspected. Which of the following findings would most strongly support the diagnosis of lactose intolerance?
content_preview: An otherwise healthy 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of episodic abdominal cramps, bloating, and flatulence. The symptoms worsen when she has pizza or ice cream and have become more frequent over the past 4 months. Lactose intolerance is suspected. Which of the following findings would most strongly support the diagnosis of lactose intolerance?
hint: Lactose intolerance does not cause bowel wall inflammation, so normal histological architecture is expected on biopsy.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical presentation of lactose intolerance, and recall its normal histological findings.

answers.content: Tall villi with focal collections of goblet cells
answers.explanation_why: Tall villi lined by simple columnar epithelium and crypts with interspaced goblet cells (crypts of Lieberkühn) and Paneth cells describes normal jejunal architecture. Patients with lactose intolerance are deficient in lactase, permitting osmotically active lactose to pass undigested to the large bowel. The molecule subsequently binds water and acts as a substrate for colonic bacteria, leading to symptoms of flatulence, bloating, and abdominal pain. Biopsy shows normal histological findings, but samples will also show decreased activity of lactase.

Villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia are not found in lactose intolerance but are characteristic biopsy findings in celiac disease. The underlying pathophysiology derives from intestinal hypersensitivity to gliadin. The clinical presentation is variable, ranging from solely gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., cramps, bloating, and steatorrhea, some of which are observed in this patient) to more systemic involvement (e.g., vitamin deficiencies and anemia, depression, dermatitis herpetiformis, fertility complications, and osteoporosis). This patient lacks diarrhea/steatorrhea or systemic signs typical of the disease and is significantly older than the typical age of first onset (usually teenage or young adulthood).

Periodic acid-Schiff-positive foamy macrophages are not found in lactose intolerance but occur in Whipple disease, caused by Tropheryma whipplei infection. This condition is very rare and most often manifests with chronic malabsorptive diarrhea and abdominal pain. It also causes weight loss, migratory nondeforming arthritis, lymphadenopathy, and a low-grade fever. The absence of these features suggests a different diagnosis.

answers.content: Partial villous atrophy with eosinophilic infiltrates
answers.explanation_why: Partial villous atrophy with eosinophilic infiltrates is not found in lactose intolerance but is one of the characteristic histological findings in cases of cow's milk allergy. This condition can manifest with abdominal pain and bloating, but is virtually exclusively seen in infants and also involves diarrhea. In contemporary practice, the diagnosis is most commonly made following an oral milk challenge or with identification of serum cow milk-specific IgE.

Noncaseating granulomas with lymphoid aggregates are not found in lactose intolerance but are classic histological findings of Crohn disease; gross findings can include cobblestone mucosa and discontinuous linear ulcers (“skip” ulcers), especially in the terminal ileum. This condition causes abdominal pain, diarrhea (which may be bloody), and extraintestinal symptoms involving the skin (pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum), the eyes (uveitis), and joints (arthritis), to name a few. This patient has none of these clinical features, and she is older than the typical age of onset (usually teenager or young adult).

answers.content: Duodenal epithelium with dense staining for chromogranin A
answers.explanation_why: Duodenal epithelium with dense staining for chromogranin A is inconsistent with lactose intolerance but is found in a subset of patients with irritable bowel syndrome. This condition also manifests with episodic abdominal cramps, bloating, and flatulence, as in this patient. Changes in stool frequency and stool form or appearance are also common. The diagnosis is most often made using the ROME IV criteria with biopsy reserved for unusual cases.

Crypt abscesses and colonic ulcerations are not found in lactose intolerance but are histological hallmarks of ulcerative colitis. Important gross morphological changes that are commonly observed include inflammation limited to mucosa and submucosa, easily friable mucosa, and continuous ulcers that consistently involve the rectum. While ulcerative colitis may present with episodic abdominal pain, frequent bloody diarrhea is an important part of the history. The absence of bloody diarrhea makes this diagnosis much less likely.

question_text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent retrosternal chest pain. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Endoscopy shows salmon pink mucosa extending 5 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsy specimens from the distal esophagus show nonciliated columnar epithelium with numerous goblet cells. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent retrosternal chest pain. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Endoscopy shows salmon pink mucosa extending 5 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsy specimens from the distal esophagus show nonciliated columnar epithelium with numerous goblet cells. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: Esophageal mucosa is normally whitish-pink and composed of stratified squamous epithelium. Intestinal mucosa is normally composed of columnar epithelium with goblet cells.
learning_objective: Recognize Barrett esophagus, and recall its etiology.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic exposure to gastric acid promotes transformation of the stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus to metaplastic columnar epithelium with goblet cells (Barrett esophagus). Barrett esophagus classically occurs in patients with GERD, which commonly presents with intermittent retrosternal pain, as seen in this patient. Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires histologic confirmation of intestinal metaplasia.

images.title: Barrett esophagus
images.description: Visible in both photographs is the transformation zone (Z-line), where the stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus (paler pink color) meets the columnar epithelium of the stomach (darker red color).Normal esophagus: the Z-line is located at or just proximal to the gastroesophageal junction, which typically corresponds to the level of the diaphragmatic hiatus and the lower esophageal sphincter.Barrett esophagus: chronic reflux esophagitis damages the stratified squamous mucosa of the distal esophagus (which is not adapted to tolerate gastric acid) → metaplastic replacement of stratified squamous epithelium by columnar epithelium → proximal displacement of the Z line

answers.content: Incomplete relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter
answers.explanation_why: Incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter occurs in patients with achalasia due to absent or decreased myenteric neurons. Although achalasia can manifest with retrosternal pain, as seen in this patient, it would classically also present with regurgitation and dysphagia of solids and liquids. Endoscopy could possibly show inflammation in case of retained food, but intestinal metaplasia would not be expected.

Neoplastic proliferation of esophageal epithelium is seen in esophageal cancer. This patient is at increased risk to develop esophageal adenocarcinoma. However, he lacks typical features of an esophageal malignancy such as weight loss, dysphagia, and an ulcerative mass on endoscopy.

Atopic inflammation of the esophagus is seen in eosinophilic esophagitis, which is thought to be caused by an abnormal response of the immune system to an antigenic stimulus. Affected individuals commonly present with retrosternal pain, dysphagia to solids, and food impaction. Although this patient presents with retrosternal pain, biopsy would likely show numerous eosinophils within multiple layers of the esophagus rather than metaplastic changes.

answers.content: Fungal infection of the lower esophagus
answers.explanation_why: Fungal infection of the esophagus can be caused by pathogens such as Candida albicans (esophageal candidiasis). Although it may cause retrosternal pain, as seen here, the absence of risk factors (e.g., immunosuppression) and fungal patches on endoscopy make this diagnosis unlikely.

Hypermotile esophageal contractions are seen in spastic disorders of the esophagus (e.g., nutcracker esophagus, diffuse esophageal spasms). Hypermotile esophagus may present with sudden, retrosternal chest pain and a distinctive pattern on barium swallow and manometry. Although this patient does have intermittent retrosternal pain, those conditions would not usually present with mucosal abnormalities.

question_text: A previously healthy 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of fever, recurrent headaches, and anorexia. One month ago, she returned from a camping trip in Chile. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F). Examination shows a swelling in the left periorbital region and axillary, cervical, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. A blood sample is obtained. Processing of the sample with which of the following methods is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A previously healthy 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of fever, recurrent headaches, and anorexia. One month ago, she returned from a camping trip in Chile. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F). Examination shows a swelling in the left periorbital region and axillary, cervical, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. A blood sample is obtained. Processing of the sample with which of the following methods is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: This patient traveled to an area where Chagas disease is endemic (Central and South America) and now presents with features of infection (e.g., high fever, lymphadenopathy) and unilateral periorbital swelling (Romana sign), which are very characteristic of acute Chagas disease.
learning_objective: Recognize acute Chagas disease, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Chagas disease is caused by the protozoa Trypanosoma cruzi, which is transmitted by inoculation of fecal material of the triatomine reduvid bug into skin or mucous membranes. The reduvid bug preferentially bites on the face (“kissing bug”). The Romana sign occurs when the portal of entry of T. cruzi is the conjunctiva or eyelid. The pathogen subsequently disseminates via the bloodstream. Staining this patient's peripheral blood with stains that contain aniline dyes (e.g, Giemsa stain, Wright stain) would likely reveal the presence of Trypanosoma cruzi trypomastigotes. Treatment with benznidazole or nifurtimox is necessary to prevent complications of Chagas disease such as dilated cardiomyopathy, megaesophagus, and acute megacolon.

images.title: Trypanosoma cruzi
images.description: Blood smear (Giemsa stain, 100x magnification)The parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, can be seen in the center of this blood smear (green overlay). Its characteristic flagellum (yellow overlay) is clearly recognizable.

answers.explanation_why: Glycogen staining methods, such as in periodic acid-Schiff stains, are useful in diagnosing Whipple disease. Although this patient does present with nonspecific symptoms of infection (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy), she does not have the enteropathic arthritis, neurological symptoms, or chronic diarrhea and insidious malabsorption typical for Whipple disease. Rather, her unilateral periorbital swelling is characteristic of Chagas disease.

images.title: PAS-positive foam cells in Whipple's disease
images.description: Photomicrograph (very high magnification, Periodic acid-Schiff stain) of a duodenal biopsyWithin the cytoplasm of the macrophages, granular PAS-positive material is visible.This appearance is suggestive of Whipple disease, which is caused by Tropheryma whippleii.

answers.explanation_why: Staining with crystal violet dyes (e.g., Gram stain) is the standard approach for identifying and classifying bacteria in a specimen. Although this patient does present with nonspecific symptoms of infection (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy), and Gram stain would be useful for excluding a bacterial cause, her unilateral periorbital swelling in particular warrants an initial diagnostic step toward diagnosing Chagas disease, which is caused by a protozoan.

Mycolic acid staining (e.g. Ziehl-Neelsen stain) is used to identify acid-fast organisms such as mycobacteria. Tuberculosis (TB) can present with a myriad of symptoms, including those seen here (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy). However, her unilateral periorbital swelling warrants an initial diagnostic step toward diagnosing Chagas disease instead.

images.title: Mycobacterium tuberculosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Ziehl-Neelsen stain; 1000× magnification)The curved, rod-shaped bacteria appear bright red after staining.

answers.explanation_why: India ink staining is used to identify the thick polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus neoformans, which most typically causes pneumonia and meningoencephalitis in immunocompromised patients. Although this patient does have symptoms indicating some type of infection (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy), disseminated lymphadenopathy and unilateral periorbital swelling after travel abroad is not consistent with C. neoformans infection in a previously healthy patient.

images.title: Cryptococcus neoformans
images.description: Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

answers.explanation_why: A stain that reacts with iron (Prussian blue stain) is used to identify iron deposits (e.g., hemosiderin in hemochromatosis, ferruginous bodies in asbestosis, marrow sideroblasts in sideroblastic anemia). This patient has features of an infection (e.g., high fever, lymphadenopathy). Stains containing iron (e.g, colloidal iron stain, iron-hematoxylin trichome stain) can be used to stain pathogens that are rich in mucopolysaccharides but stains that react with iron are rarely used in clinical microbiology.

images.title: Hemochromatosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a liver tissue sample (Prussian blue stain)Prussian blue stains the iron deposits dark blue (green arrows) and the nuclei bright red. A portal triad (P; green overlay) is visible in the lower left corner.

answers.explanation_why: Silver staining is useful for identifying fungi (e.g., Coccidioides) as well as some bacteria (e.g., H. pylori, Legionella pneumophila). Legionella pneumophila infection (legionellosis) could cause the nonspecific features seen here (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy) but it would also cause respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough) or GI symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, diarrhea), which are not reported by this patient. Unilateral periorbital swelling is characteristic of Chagas disease, which cannot be diagnosed by silver stain.

images.title: Coccidioides immitis
images.description: Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of  coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

question_text: An 11-year-old girl comes to the physician with her mother because of a 2-day history of passing “cola-colored“ urine. During the past week, her mother noticed episodes of facial swelling. The patient had a rash on her face about 4 weeks ago. A renal biopsy after immunofluorescence is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: An 11-year-old girl comes to the physician with her mother because of a 2-day history of passing “cola-colored“ urine. During the past week, her mother noticed episodes of facial swelling. The patient had a rash on her face about 4 weeks ago. A renal biopsy after immunofluorescence is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's renal biopsy specimen shows diffuse granular deposition on immunofluorescence, which is characteristic of immune complex diseases.
learning_objective: Recognize poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.

answers.explanation_why: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an acute glomerular inflammation caused by the deposition of immune complexes along the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium in response to infection with nephritogenic strains of group A streptococci (GAS). PSGN classically occurs in children 1–6 weeks after infection (e.g., impetigo) and manifests with periorbital (or generalized) edema and gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine), both of which are seen in this patient. In addition, PSGN can also manifest with hypertension, azotemia, and proteinuria. Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 create a characteristic “lumpy-bumpy” appearance on immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen.

images.title: C3 deposits in poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis
images.description: Immunofluorescence photomicrograph of a renal biopsy specimen (very high magnification)Subepithelial deposits of C3 are seen distributed within the capillary loops. The deposits are visible as bright green fluorescence in an irregular granular pattern.This finding is typical of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.

answers.explanation_why: Alport syndrome, a hereditary type of glomerulonephritis caused by a mutation in type IV collagen, can manifest with gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema, as seen in this patient. However, this condition is most commonly inherited in an X-linked pattern, with females rarely being affected. Moreover, Alport syndrome is characterized by additional features, such as sensorineural deafness and multiple eye disorders (e.g., lens dislocation), as well as a positive family history of kidney failure and hearing loss, none of which is present here. In addition, immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen would show an absence of type IV collagen rather than the granular immune complex deposition seen here.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in black and Hispanic populations as well as the most common cause of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome in children. FSGS can be primary (i.e., idiopathic), secondary (e.g., associated with heroin use, HIV or HBV infection, sickle cell disease), or genetic. This patient has had multiple episodes of facial edema, which is consistent with this diagnosis; however, gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) would be an unlikely finding in FSGS. In addition, immunofluorescence in FSGS is typically unremarkable but may show IgM and C3 deposition within sclerotic lesions. It would not show the diffuse granular appearance seen here.

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in childhood, which can manifest with facial edema, as seen in this patient. MCD is thought to result from injury to podocytes and is typically triggered by a recent infection or immunization in an otherwise healthy child. However, the presence of gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) is inconsistent with this diagnosis. In addition, immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen would show normal-appearing glomeruli rather than the granular deposition seen here.

IgA nephropathy is a type of glomerulonephritis caused by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the mesangium. It is most common in children and young adults and can manifest with gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema, which are seen in this patient. Immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen typically shows granular deposition in the mesangium (mostly IgA). However, hematuria due to IgA nephropathy usually occurs concurrently with nonspecific respiratory, or less commonly, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infections. This patient instead presents in the postinfectious period, 4 weeks after having a rash, suggesting another diagnosis.

Membranous nephropathy (MN) is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in white adults. Renal biopsy specimens in patients with MN typically show immune complex deposits (mostly IgG and C3) on immunofluorescence, which are seen here. MN rarely manifests in childhood; however, when children are affected, the most common associations include hepatitis B infection and autoimmune or thyroid disease, none of which is present in this patient. Although MN can manifest with facial edema, gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) would be an unlikely finding. Moreover, this patient's recent rash suggests another diagnosis.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), a rare glomerular disease that most commonly appears in childhood and early adulthood, often manifests with both nephritic and nephrotic syndrome. Based on immunofluorescence examination, there are two major types of MPGN. Immunoglobulin-mediated MPGN (type I), which is often secondary to hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection, typically involves granular deposition along the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium, as seen in this patient's biopsy. Immunofluorescence microscopy of complement-mediated MPGN (type II) typically shows C3 deposition in the glomerular capillary wall, but no granular pattern. Although both types of MPGN can manifest with gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema, the patient's recent rash suggests another diagnosis.

Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN), which is most commonly caused by systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune conditions, often manifests with both nephritic and nephrotic syndrome. In SLE-associated DPGN, granular depositions are typically seen on immunofluorescence (staining positive for IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, C4, and C1q, the “full-house” pattern). SLE can manifest with a facial rash, and, in the case of renal involvement, gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema. However, this patient lacks other typical symptoms of SLE (e.g., fever, fatigue, arthritis), making this diagnosis unlikely.

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is characterized by quickly deteriorating renal function and can manifest with gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema, which are seen here. The various etiologies of RPGN are typically distinguished with immunofluorescence. Although immune complex-mediated RPGN (e.g., lupus nephritis, Henoch-Schonlein purpura) shows granular deposits on immunofluorescence, as seen in this patient's renal biopsy, further symptoms such as fatigue, decreased urine output, and flank pain would be expected in a patient with RPGN.

images.title: Acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN)
images.description: Fluorescence microscopy (immunofluorescence staining for C3; high magnification)Granular deposits of C3 are visible, resulting in a starry sky pattern.

question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for blurry vision for the past 2 months. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows joint hypermobility, a high-arched palate, and abnormally long, slender fingers and toes. Slit lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. This patient's findings are most likely caused by a defect in which of the following structural proteins?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for blurry vision for the past 2 months. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows joint hypermobility, a high-arched palate, and abnormally long, slender fingers and toes. Slit lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. This patient's findings are most likely caused by a defect in which of the following structural proteins?
hint: This patient presents with features of Marfan syndrome (i.e., tall stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, joint hypermobility, and superotemporal lens subluxation).
learning_objective: Recognize Marfan syndrome, and recall the associated defective structural protein.

answers.explanation_why: Defective laminin can cause junctional epidermolysis bullosa, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in laminin.

Defective type III collagen is the cause of vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which presents primarily with cardiovascular manifestations. These include heart valve defects (especially mitral valve prolapse), aneurysms or dissections of large arteries (e.g., aortic, iliac), and berry aneurysms of cerebral arteries. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type III collagen.

Marfan syndrome is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene, which encodes fibrillin, an extracellular matrix glycoprotein that forms a supportive sheath around elastin. Abnormal elastin production leads to defective connective tissue and excessive growth factor release. Further features of Marfan syndrome include vascular abnormalities (e.g., aortic aneurysm or dissection).

Defective type I collagen is the cause of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). Patients with OI can present with joint hypermobility, as seen in this patient, but do not develop lens subluxation, high-arched palate, tall stature, or arachnodactyly. Moreover, patients with OI typically have a history of multiple fractures in the setting of minimal trauma along with blue sclerae and hearing loss. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type I collagen.
Defective keratin can cause epidermolysis bullosa simplex, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in keratin.

question_text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of severe abdominal pain, bloating, and episodic diarrhea. She has also had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss over the past 10 months. Physical examination shows a mildly distended abdomen, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and multiple erythematous, tender nodules on the anterior aspect of both legs. There is a small draining lesion in the perianal region. Further evaluation of this patient's gastrointestinal tract is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of severe abdominal pain, bloating, and episodic diarrhea. She has also had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss over the past 10 months. Physical examination shows a mildly distended abdomen, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and multiple erythematous, tender nodules on the anterior aspect of both legs. There is a small draining lesion in the perianal region. Further evaluation of this patient's gastrointestinal tract is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain, diarrhea, and a perianal fistula with drainage in combination with erythema nodosum (multiple erythematous, tender nodules on the legs) are suggestive of a diagnosis of Crohn disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Crohn disease, and recall its characteristic gastrointestinal findings.

answers.explanation_why: Villous atrophy is a typical histopathologic finding in celiac disease. This condition can manifest with abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea, and weight loss. However, extraintestinal symptoms are more common (e.g., vitamin deficiencies, dermatitis herpetiformis, depression, osteoporosis). This patient's erythema nodosum and fistulas are not associated with celiac disease.

images.title: Histopathological changes in celiac disease
images.description: Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of duodenal tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)Intraepithelial lymphocytosis (examples indicated by arrowheads), villous atrophy (dashed outline showing the approximate height of a normal villus), and crypt hyperplasia (example indicated by green overlay) are visible.Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.explanation_why: Crypt abscesses are a typical histopathologic finding in ulcerative colitis (UC). They are also seen in patients with Crohn disease but are far more common in patients with UC. UC can manifest with erythema nodosum, severe abdominal pain, bloating, and episodic diarrhea. However, it is quite rare to see fistula formation in UC because inflammation is localized in the mucosal and submucosal layers.

images.title: Ulcerative colitis
images.description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.explanation_why: No structural abnormalities of the gastrointestinal tract in a patient with abdominal pain, bloating, and episodic diarrhea would be concerning for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Though IBS could cause some of this patient's symptoms, it is not associated with findings like erythema nodosum or fistulas. In addition, patients with IBS generally appear healthy and do not typically manifest with weight loss.

Melanosis coli is a benign hyperpigmentation of the colonic epithelium seen in patients who abuse laxatives. Laxative abuse would cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss, which are seen in this patient; however, it would not explain the presence of erythema nodosum or fistulas.

images.title: Melanosis coli
images.description: Endoscopic view of the colon in a patient with a history of laxative abuseThe colonic mucosa is lined with a pattern of sharply demarcated, dark brown hyperpigmentations, caused by the deposition of anthraquinone pigments from a plant-based laxative (e.g., senna gylcosides or aloe emodin) in the mucosa. The mucosa's surface texture and the colon's haustral folds are unchanged.

answers.explanation_why: Neuroendocrine tumor cells are found in carcinoid tumors. Diarrhea and abdominal cramps may occur as part of carcinoid syndrome, but they are usually accompanied by other findings such as cutaneous flushing and bronchospasm (e.g., wheezing, dyspnea). Moreover, carcinoid tumors are not associated with erythema nodosum or fistulas.

Transmural intestinal inflammation is a characteristic finding of Crohn disease. It commonly results in abscess and fistula formation. Endoscopy confirms the diagnosis, showing a discontinuous pattern of involvement with linear ulcers (“snail trails”) and a cobblestone appearance of the affected GI areas (typically terminal ileum and colon). Biopsy reveals inflammation of all intestinal layers and noncaseating granulomas.

images.title: Crohn disease
images.description: Photomicrograph of a colon biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)Infiltrating neutrophils (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen in the crypts in the upper part of the image. A noncaseating granuloma (green overlay) is visible in the lower part of the image.These features indicate transmural inflammation, which is a characteristic finding of Crohn disease.

question_text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of memory loss. Three weeks ago, he had a cardiac arrest that required cardiopulmonary resuscitation and intravenous epinephrine. On mental status examination, he cannot recall objects shown to him 20 minutes earlier but vividly recalls memories from before the incident. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following structures of the brain is most likely affected?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of memory loss. Three weeks ago, he had a cardiac arrest that required cardiopulmonary resuscitation and intravenous epinephrine. On mental status examination, he cannot recall objects shown to him 20 minutes earlier but vividly recalls memories from before the incident. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following structures of the brain is most likely affected?
hint: This patient presents with features of an ischemic stroke following a cardiac arrest. The short-term memory loss indicates selective neuronal necrosis of a structure within the limbic system.
learning_objective: Recognize anterograde amnesia, and recall the brain structure involved in short-term memory.

answers.explanation_why: Cerebellar Purkinje cells are very vulnerable to ischemic insults. However, patients with ischemic damage to this group of cells would present with intention tremor, nystagmus, and ataxia.

Microglial cells are relatively resistant to ischemic insults because they are not as metabolically active as neurons. In fact, these macrophages are typically seen in the inflammatory reaction to cellular injury after ischemia. Strokes affecting the dorsal midbrain present with Parinaud syndrome, not memory impairment.

answers.content: Internal pyramidal layer of the amygdala
answers.explanation_why: The amygdala is a complex of nuclei located in the temporal lobe, it is not composed of cellular layers like the neocortex or hippocampus. Moreover, strokes affecting the amygdala typically result in uninhibited, aggressive behavior (Kluver-Bucy syndrome).

answers.content: External pyramidal layer of the parietal cortex
answers.explanation_why: The external pyramidal layer of the parietal cortex is very vulnerable to ischemic injury. However, neuronal cell death in the dominant parietal cortex would lead to Gerstmann syndrome, not anterograde amnesia as seen here.

Damage to the pyramidal cells of the hippocampus typically leads to anterograde amnesia, as seen in this patient. The hippocampus is the brain region most vulnerable to ischemic hypoxia, and only a few minutes of ischemia can lead to irreversible damage mediated by cytotoxic glutamatergic release and uptake. Other brain regions that are particularly susceptible to ischemic insults are neocortical pyramidal cells, striatal neurons, and Purkinje cells.

Astroglial cells (also known as astrocytes) of the putamen are relatively resistant to ischemic injury mainly because they can use glycogen stores for anaerobic metabolism. Moreover, injury to the cells of the putamen results in impaired voluntary muscle control rather than memory loss. Following an ischemic event, astrocytes become reactive and form a glial scar (reactive gliosis).

question_text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and intermittent diarrhea. During this time, he has had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the lower quadrants. A photograph from a colonoscopy of the descending colon is shown. Similar findings are seen in the sigmoid colon and rectum. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and intermittent diarrhea. During this time, he has had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the lower quadrants. A photograph from a colonoscopy of the descending colon is shown. Similar findings are seen in the sigmoid colon and rectum. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient has symptoms typical of inflammatory bowel disease. Conjunctival pallor indicates anemia, possibly due to chronic gastrointestinal bleeding. The colonoscopy shows continuous mucosal inflammation with fibrin-covered ulcerations and loss of superficial vascular markings, which is highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC).
learning_objective: Recognize ulcerative colitis, and recall its associated antibody marker.

answers.explanation_why: A lactose hydrogen breath test is positive in lactose malabsorption, which is characterized by an inability to digest lactose due to lactase deficiency. Lactose malabsorption also causes diarrhea and abdominal cramps. However, symptoms usually also include bloating and occur after consuming dairy products. Additionally, patients with lactase deficiency have a macroscopically normal colonic mucosa.

Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCAs) are associated with inflammatory bowel disease, particularly with Crohn disease (up to 70% of cases). Crohn disease can manifest with nonbloody chronic diarrhea, fatigue, lower abdominal pain, weight loss, and anemia. However, characteristic colonoscopic findings include multiple, sharply delineated areas of inflammation and intervening areas of normal mucosa. The delineated regions coalesce to form long, serpiginous ulcers between normal mucosa, thus giving the mucosa a cobblestone appearance. Small aphthous ulcerations arranged in a longitudinal fashion may also be present. This patient's colonoscopic findings indicate UC, which is associated with ASCAs in only 20% of cases.

images.title: Colon in Crohn disease
images.description: Endoscopic view of the colonMultiple linear and serpiginous ulcerations covered with fibrinous exudate can be seen. The mucosa between the ulcerations is erythematous and has lost its normal vascular pattern.These findings are characteristic of Crohn disease.

answers.explanation_why: Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCAs) are positive in up to 70% of patients with UC, with no correlation between the titer and disease activity. While serologic testing is not recommended for definitive diagnosis or exclusion of UC, it can support the diagnosis. An increase in p-ANCAs is also seen in patients with other inflammatory disorders, including autoimmune systemic vasculitis (especially microscopic polyangiitis) and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

images.title: Acute ulcerative colitis
images.description: Endoscopic view of the sigmoid colonThe mucosa is erythematous and edematous. There is a loss of superficial vascular markings. Several linear, semi-confluent ulcerations (green overlay) are visible.These findings are characteristic of acute ulcerative colitis.

answers.explanation_why: PAS-positive cytoplasmic granules in the intestinal mucosa are seen in patients with Whipple disease, an infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei. Symptoms include diarrhea, fatigue, and weight loss due to malabsorption. However, this condition occurs more commonly in elderly men, and colonoscopy would show pale yellow, eroded patches rather than ulcerations.

Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are present in over 90% of patients with celiac disease (CD). Symptoms of CD can include diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue (due to malabsorption and vitamin deficiencies). However, endoscopy would demonstrate villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia (a smooth or atrophic mucous membrane), not ulcerations. Moreover, CD is a disease of the small intestine, the colon is not typically affected.

images.title: Celiac disease
images.description: Endoscopic view of the duodenumThe surface of the duodenum is smooth, with small notches forming a mosaic pattern. Villous atrophy and hyperplastic crypts (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible.These findings are characteristic of celiac disease.

images.title: Acute ulcerative colitis
images.description: Endoscopic view of the colonThe mucosa is erythematous and edematous. There is a loss of superficial vascular markings. Mucosal granularity and ulcerations (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible.These findings are characteristic of acute ulcerative colitis.

question_text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 2-month history of mild abdominal pain, nausea, and several episodes of vomiting. She often feels full after eating only a small amount of food. Abdominal examination shows mild right upper quadrant tenderness and a liver span of 16 cm. Ultrasonography shows a 5 x 4 cm hyperechoic mass in the left lobe of the liver. The mass is surgically excised. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 2-month history of mild abdominal pain, nausea, and several episodes of vomiting. She often feels full after eating only a small amount of food. Abdominal examination shows mild right upper quadrant tenderness and a liver span of 16 cm. Ultrasonography shows a 5 x 4 cm hyperechoic mass in the left lobe of the liver. The mass is surgically excised. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The photomicrograph shows numerous cystic spaces lined by a single layer of endothelium. The cysts contain erythrocytes and multiple thromboses. There is no evidence of normal hepatic parenchyma.
learning_objective: Recognize cavernous hemangioma of the liver.

answers.explanation_why: Hepatocellular adenoma (HA) is a benign tumor of the liver that is typically seen in women aged 20–45 years. HA mainly occurs in individuals on long-term use of oral contraceptives or steroids. HA is usually asymptomatic and is often detected incidentally. On sonography, HA is seen as a well-demarcated, heteroechoic intraparenchymal lesion. Histopathological features of HA include enlarged benign hepatocytes that contain glycogen and lipid deposits, which are not seen in this specimen.

images.title: Hepatocellular adenoma
images.description:
Photomicrograph of a biopsy from a hepatic nodule (H&E stain)Sheets of hepatocytes arranged in two-cell thick cords are visible.
The cytoplasm of most hepatocytes is pale or clear, indicating intracytoplasmic glycogen accumulation.
There is no nuclear atypia.
The normal hepatic architecture of hexagonal lobules with a central vein and surrounding portal triads is absent.This disorganized mass of benign hepatocytes is the characteristic histological appearance of a hepatocellular adenoma.

answers.explanation_why: Alveolar echinococcosis is a rare parasitic infection that mostly affects the liver and causes intraparenchymal lesions. Hepatic lesions can manifest with upper abdominal pain and hepatomegaly, which are seen in this patient. Imaging would show anechoic cysts with or without septae and areas of calcification. On histopathology, the walls of echinococcal cysts are seen as lamellated membranes, surrounded by chronically inflamed hepatic parenchyma, and areas of calcification. Both of these features are absent in this specimen.

Most individuals (75–90%) with polycystic kidney disease (PKD) also have multiple hepatic cysts that typically manifest with right upper abdominal pain and hepatomegaly, which are seen in this patient. Unlike the specimen here, however, hepatic cysts in PKD are seen as multiple anechoic unilocular cysts on sonography, and histopathology would show cysts lined with cuboidal biliary epithelium and surrounded by normal hepatic parenchyma.

This patient's biopsy specimen shows a benign vascular tumor, which confirms the diagnosis of cavernous hemangioma. Cavernous hemangioma of the liver is the most common benign hepatic tumor and is typically seen in women aged 30–50 years. While most patients with hepatic hemangiomas are asymptomatic, a large hepatic hemangioma can compress the adjacent bowel (causing early satiety) and stretch the Glisson capsule (causing upper abdominal pain). Because hepatic hemangiomas are highly vascular, they typically appear as hyperechoic masses on ultrasonography. Needle aspiration or biopsy should be avoided in the diagnostic workup of hepatic hemangiomas due to the risk of hemorrhage.

images.title: Hepatic hemangioma
images.description: Ultrasound liver (transverse plane)A homogeneous hyperechoic lesion (green overlay) with a well-defined margin and no hypoechoic halo can be seen. There is slight posterior acoustic enhancement (white area). This appearance is characteristic of a hemangioma.Most hepatic hemangiomas are hyperechoic. However, they can appear hypoechoic, particularly when on a background of hyperechoic hepatic steatosis. If surrounded by a hypoechoic halo, a hyperechoic hepatic lesion must be considered suspicious for malignancy.PV: hepatic portal vein

answers.explanation_why: Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is a benign tumor of the liver that is typically seen in women aged 20–50 years. A large FNH tumor can cause hepatomegaly, abdominal pain, and early satiety, similar to the features seen in this patient. However, on imaging, FNH is seen as an intrahepatic mass of variable echogenicity, often with a central scar. In addition, a biopsy of FNH would show benign hepatocytes arranged in nodules. These nodules would be separated by fibrous septa containing aberrant blood vessels. Bile ductules and Kupffer cells would also be seen.

images.title: Focal nodular hyperplasia
images.description: Histopathological liver section (Elastica van Gieson stain): circumscribed, central local scar, which appears as a central region of connective tissue (S). The surrounding liver parenchyma shows nodular changes (L) and resembles cirrhotic tissue.

answers.explanation_why: Hepatic angiosarcoma is a rare tumor of the liver that is typically seen in men > 60 years of age. Risk factors include exposure to arsenic, vinyl chloride, and thorium dioxide. Hepatic angiosarcoma can manifest with upper abdominal pain, early satiety, and hepatomegaly, which are seen in this patient, but it also typically causes weight loss, fatigue, or ascites. Unlike the specimen here, hepatic angiosarcoma usually appears as multiple large intraparenchymal lesions with necrotic areas on sonography. Histopathology would show vascular spaces lined with dysplastic endothelium that infiltrates the hepatic cords and sinusoids.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common primary liver cancer. While HCC can manifest with upper abdominal pain, early satiety, and hepatomegaly, the most important risk factor for HCC is chronic liver disease (e.g., liver cirrhosis, chronic hepatitis B, chronic hepatitis C, hemochromatosis), which this patient does not have. On sonography, HCC appears as an intraparenchymal mass of variable echogenicity with areas of necrosis and calcification. Histopathology would show pleomorphic hepatocytes with eosinophilic cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and mitotic figures, as well as areas of necrosis and neovascularization, which is not consistent with this patient's biopsy findings.

images.title: Hepatocellular carcinoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (H&E stain; 200x magnification)The cancerous tissue (border indicated by green line) features tumor cells with granular eosinophil cytoplasm and nuclear pleomorphism (examples indicated by green arrow and green overlay). Adjacent to the neoplasm is a portal field (border indicated by red dashed line) with fibrosis, minimal inflammation, and an inconspicuous bile duct (red overlay). Normal liver tissue is not depicted here.This is the appearance of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma.

images.title: Cavernous hemangioma of the liver
images.description: Photomicrograph of a hepatic nodule biopsy specimen (H&E stain)Numerous cystic spaces lined by a single layer of endothelial cells are visible throughout this microscopic field (examples indicated by green overlay). The cyst walls are thin and composed of smooth muscle, elastic tissue, and fibrous tissue. Multiple thrombi (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible within the cysts.This histopathological appearance is characteristic of cavernous liver hemangioma.

question_text: A 61-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of crushing substernal chest pain at rest for the past 2 hours. She is diaphoretic. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg. An ECG shows ST elevation in I, aVL, and V2–V4. Coronary angiography shows an 80% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery. Which of the following is the most likely initial step in the pathogenesis of this patient's coronary condition?
content_preview: A 61-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of crushing substernal chest pain at rest for the past 2 hours. She is diaphoretic. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg. An ECG shows ST elevation in I, aVL, and V2–V4. Coronary angiography shows an 80% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery. Which of the following is the most likely initial step in the pathogenesis of this patient's coronary condition?
hint: This patient's symptoms (acute, crushing substernal chest pain, diaphoresis) and ECG changes indicate a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome (ACS). The angiography showing a stenosis of the left anterior descending artery confirms the diagnosis. ACS is caused primarily by atherosclerosis.
learning_objective: Recognize acute coronary syndrome, and recall the initial step in atherosclerosis pathogenesis.

answers.explanation_why: The development of atherosclerosis begins with an external factor (e.g., hypertension, smoking, advanced glycation end-products) damaging the endothelium, which increases adhesiveness and leads to local inflammation and invasion of smooth muscle cells into the tunica intima. Inflammatory cytokines attract macrophages, which then form foam cells by taking up cholesterol from oxidized low-density lipids. These foam cells accumulate to form fatty streaks (early atherosclerotic lesions). Finally, collagen production by lipid-laden macrophages and smooth muscle cells form these fatty streaks into a fibrous plaque.

Intimal monocyte infiltration is one of the first steps in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. After adhesion to the endothelium, the monocytes emigrate through the endothelium into the intima. As the endothelium is physiologically impermeable to monocytes, monocyte infiltration is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

Intimal smooth muscle cells migration is mediated by macrophages producing platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and fibroblast growth factor (FGF). However, intimal smooth muscle cell migration is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

Intimal foam cell accumulation is a consequence of macrophages infiltrating the intima and ingesting cholesterol from oxidized LDL. These foam cells accumulate and form fatty streaks. However, intimal foam cell accumulation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

Fibrous plaque formation is mediated by macrophages, lymphocytes, and smooth muscle cells. Together with deposited extracellular matrix (e.g., collagen), these cell types form the fibrous plaque in atherosclerosis. However, fibrous plaque formation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

Platelet activation releases a variety of inflammatory mediators and thereby recruits inflammatory cells towards the site of the atherosclerotic lesion. However, platelets are only activated after adhesion to the endothelium of affected vessels. Therefore, platelet activation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) oxidation releases cholesterol, which is then ingested by macrophages, inducing foam cell formation. However, attraction and activation of macrophages happen before the formation of foam cells. Therefore, LDL oxidation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman who recently emigrated to the USA from Japan comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of night sweats, malaise, and joint pain. During this time, she has also had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows weak brachial and radial pulses. There are tender subcutaneous nodules on both legs. Carotid bruits are heard on auscultation bilaterally. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 96 mm/h. A CT scan of the chest shows thickening and narrowing of the aortic arch. Microscopic examination of the aortic arch is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman who recently emigrated to the USA from Japan comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of night sweats, malaise, and joint pain. During this time, she has also had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows weak brachial and radial pulses. There are tender subcutaneous nodules on both legs. Carotid bruits are heard on auscultation bilaterally. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 96 mm/h. A CT scan of the chest shows thickening and narrowing of the aortic arch. Microscopic examination of the aortic arch is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient's findings of weak peripheral pulses, carotid bruits, elevated ESR, and thickening of the aortic arch should raise concern for Takayasu arteritis. This type of large vessel vasculitis predominantly occurs in women under the age of 40 years (especially those with Asian ancestry).
learning_objective: Recognize Takayasu arteritis, and recall its histopathological features.

answers.content: Fibrinoid necrosis of the intima and media
answers.explanation_why: Fibrinoid necrosis of the tunica intima and tunica media are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), which can manifest with fever, night sweats, malaise, arthralgia, and erythema nodosum. However, PAN involves small- to medium-sized arteries (e.g., renal arteries, vasa nervorum, arteries supplying the intestines, and cutaneous vessels) rather than large vessels, which are affected in this patient.

images.title: Polyarteritis nodosa
images.description: Photomicrograph of a muscle biopsy sample with a medium-sized arterial vessel (H&E stain; low magnification)There is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.These findings are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

answers.explanation_why:
The hallmark of Takayasu arteritis (TA) is granulomatous inflammation of the arterial wall affecting the large arteries (typically the aorta and its branches). TA is more common among women with Asian ancestry, and its peak incidence is between 15 and 45 years of age. This condition manifests with systemic features that include fever, malaise, and arthralgia. Other features of TA include decreased brachial and radial pulses (pulseless disease), syncope, carotid bruit, angina pectoris, impaired vision, and Raynaud phenomenon, all of which are due to narrowing of the large arteries. Erythema nodosum and urticaria may also be seen in TA. Microscopic examination of the diseased vessels would show granulomatous inflammation of the vessel walls, with inflammatory cells infiltrating the tunica media and tunica adventitia.

Patients with Takayasu arteritis should be treated with corticosteroids.

images.title: Great vessel stenoses
images.description: Angiography thoracic aorta (left anterior oblique view) of a patient with Takayasu arteritisStenoses (examples indicated by white arrows) are seen in the innominate (I), left common carotid (C), and left subclavian (S) arteries. An injection catheter is seen in the dilated ascending aorta (green overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Subendothelial hyaline deposition is a form of arteriolosclerosis commonly seen in individuals with chronic essential hypertension and/or diabetes. It can also be part of the normal aging process. However, thickening of the aortic arch, erythema nodosum, and the systemic symptoms of night sweats, malaise, joint pain, and weight loss are not associated with hyaline deposits. Furthermore, this patient is 32 years of age and has none of the risk factors for hyaline deposition.

Immune complex deposition is characteristic of Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP), which is a small vessel vasculitis that can manifest with malaise, arthralgia, and cutaneous lesions. However, the cutaneous lesions of HSP are nontender palpable purpura rather than tender nodules (erythema nodosum). Moreover, decreased peripheral pulses and involvement of large vessels (e.g., aorta, brachial arteries) would not be expected. Instead, HSP manifests with other features, such as nephritic syndrome (due to IgA nephropathy) and abdominal pain.

Mönckeberg arteriosclerosis is characterized by calcification of the tunica media, and it is associated with diabetes mellitus. This condition usually affects the smaller vessels in the extremities and is not associated with stenosis. Furthermore, thickening of the aortic arch, erythema nodosum, and the systemic symptoms of night sweats, malaise, joint pain, and weight loss are not associated with Mönckeberg arteriosclerosis.

question_text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 20 minutes after having a seizure. Over the past 3 days, he has had a fever and worsening headaches. This morning, his wife noticed that he was irritable and demonstrated strange behavior; he put the back of his fork, the salt shaker, and the lid of the coffee can into his mouth. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows diffuse hyperreflexia and an extensor response to the plantar reflex on the right. A T2-weighted MRI of the brain shows edema and areas of hemorrhage in the left temporal lobe. Which of the following is most likely the primary mechanism of the development of edema in this patient?
content_preview: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 20 minutes after having a seizure. Over the past 3 days, he has had a fever and worsening headaches. This morning, his wife noticed that he was irritable and demonstrated strange behavior; he put the back of his fork, the salt shaker, and the lid of the coffee can into his mouth. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows diffuse hyperreflexia and an extensor response to the plantar reflex on the right. A T2-weighted MRI of the brain shows edema and areas of hemorrhage in the left temporal lobe. Which of the following is most likely the primary mechanism of the development of edema in this patient?
hint: The patient’s history of fever, headaches, seizure, focal neurologic findings (e.g., hyperreflexia and extensor response to plantar reflex), and MRI showing edema and hemorrhage in the temporal lobe suggest HSV encephalitis.
learning_objective: Recognize HSV encephalitis, and recall the pathologic mechanism underlying vasogenic edema.

answers.content: Release of vascular endothelial growth factor
answers.explanation_why: Release of vascular endothelial growth factor is one of the pathologic mechanisms of edema in brain tumors. This patient’s headache, seizure, and focal neurologic deficits are early signs of a brain tumor. However, an acute onset of symptoms and fever are more consistent with an infectious etiology.

Cellular retention of sodium leading to fluid retention and cellular swelling is the pathologic mechanism of cytotoxic edema, a complication of acute ischemic stroke. Ischemic stroke can manifest with headache, seizure, and focal neurologic findings (e.g., hyperreflexia and extensor response to plantar reflex). However, T2-weighted MRI in acute ischemic stroke typically shows hyperintensity with no hemorrhages. Furthermore, an acute ischemic stroke would not explain this patient's fever.

Breakdown of endothelial tight junctions causing damage to the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is the pathologic mechanism underlying vasogenic edema. Disruption of the BBB leads to extravasation of fluid and proteins into the extracellular space of the cerebral parenchyma, leading to increased intracranial pressure and neuronal dysfunction. This mechanism of edema development can also be due to other inflammatory conditions, metastasis, trauma, or lead poisoning.

The patient's behavioral change (putting the fork, salt shaker, and coffee can lid in his mouth) is characteristic of hyperorality, a finding in Kluver-Bucy syndrome. This condition is a possible complication of HSV encephalitis.

Degranulation of eosinophils is part of the pathologic mechanism of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction. This reaction is characterized by tissue swelling and edema due to increased histamine release and increased vascular permeability. However, this mechanism does not play a role in the pathophysiology of cerebral edema.

Increased hydrostatic pressure is the pathologic mechanism underlying hypertensive encephalopathy, which causes severe headaches, seizures, and focal neurologic symptoms (e.g., hyperreflexia and extensor response to plantar reflex). However, hypertensive encephalopathy does not typically cause fever. Furthermore, this patient’s blood pressure is within the normal range.

question_text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of a severely itchy rash. She initially noticed a small, itchy bump that gradually became a generalized rash. She reports that the itching is extremely bothersome and often wakes her up at night. Yesterday, she also noticed a lump in the left axilla. She has used over-the-counter emollients to decrease the intensity of the rash, but they have not had any notable effect. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. She has osteoarthritis of the knees, for which she takes daily ibuprofen. Examination shows diffuse erythroderma with fine scales involving the neck, shoulders, back, abdomen, and extremities. The nails appear normal. There is generalized lymphadenopathy. A peripheral blood smear shows numerous atypical cells with highly grooved nuclei. This patient's condition is most likely caused by abnormal proliferation of which of the following types of cells?
content_preview: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of a severely itchy rash. She initially noticed a small, itchy bump that gradually became a generalized rash. She reports that the itching is extremely bothersome and often wakes her up at night. Yesterday, she also noticed a lump in the left axilla. She has used over-the-counter emollients to decrease the intensity of the rash, but they have not had any notable effect. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. She has osteoarthritis of the knees, for which she takes daily ibuprofen. Examination shows diffuse erythroderma with fine scales involving the neck, shoulders, back, abdomen, and extremities. The nails appear normal. There is generalized lymphadenopathy. A peripheral blood smear shows numerous atypical cells with highly grooved nuclei. This patient's condition is most likely caused by abnormal proliferation of which of the following types of cells?
hint: Diffuse erythroderma with intense pruritus, generalized lymphadenopathy, and a peripheral blood smear that shows numerous atypical cells with highly grooved (cerebriform) nuclei are consistent with a diagnosis of Sézary syndrome (SS).
learning_objective: Recognize Sézary syndrome, and recall its associated cell type.

answers.explanation_why: Abnormal proliferation of keratinocytes does not occur in SS, but in several dermatologic conditions, including psoriasis and nonmelanoma skin cancers. Psoriasis typically manifests with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silver-white scales on the scalp, back, and extensor surfaces. Erythroderma is an uncommon manifestation of psoriasis. Nonmelanoma skin cancers manifest with discrete lesions, most commonly in sun-exposed areas of skin; they do not cause erythroderma. In addition, these conditions do not manifest with generalized lymphadenopathy or atypical cells with highly grooved (cerebriform) nuclei on a peripheral blood smear.

SS is a subtype of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) characterized by leukemic dissemination of malignant T cells in the skin. This condition can evolve from mycosis fungoides (another CTCL subtype) or arise de novo. The evaluation of SS should include a skin biopsy to assess cell morphology, immunophenotype, and clonality as well as a peripheral blood smear with flow cytometry and clonality studies. The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of Sézary cells (atypical T cells with cerebriform nuclei) in the peripheral blood. Treatments include skin-directed therapies (e.g., topical corticosteroids, topical nitrogen mustards) and systemic therapies (e.g., phototherapy, chemotherapy, monoclonal antibodies).

images.title: Sézary Cell
images.description: Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa staining)In the center, there is an atypical lymphocyte. The cell is large (approximately twice the size of the surrounding erythrocytes) with light purple (basophilic) cytoplasm, and a convoluted or “brain-like” (cerebriform) dark purple nucleus.This is the typical appearance of a Sézary cell, a lymphocyte that occurs in Sézary syndrome (a form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma).

answers.explanation_why: Abnormal proliferation of plasma cells occurs in plasma cell dyscrasias, such as multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma can rarely manifest with cutaneous plasmacytomas, which typically appear as purple-red, subcutaneous nodules, but it does not cause erythroderma. In addition, multiple myeloma does not typically cause generalized lymphadenopathy or pruritus. SS, which this patient has, is not caused by abnormal proliferation of plasma cells.

Abnormal proliferation of myeloblasts occurs in acute myelogenous leukemia (AML), which can rarely manifest with generalized lymphadenopathy and pruritus. AML can also cause cutaneous lesions (leukemia cutis). However, leukemia cutis typically manifests with discrete, nodular lesions; it does not cause erythroderma. In addition, myeloblasts on peripheral blood smear appear as immature cells with large nuclei and prominent nucleoli and may show Auer rods; they do not have highly grooved (cerebriform) nuclei. SS, which this patient has, is not caused by abnormal proliferation of myeloblasts.

Abnormal proliferation of B cells occurs in B-cell lymphomas. These malignancies can be further categorized into Hodgkin lymphomas, which are characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells, and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, which comprise all other types. Patients with B-cell lymphomas typically develop localized lymphadenopathy (not generalized) and have B symptoms, which are not seen in this patient. In addition, B-cell lymphomas do not cause erythroderma. SS, which this patient has, is not caused by abnormal proliferation of B cells.

question_text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 1-week history of fever and fatigue. During this period, she has also had decreased appetite and a 1.5-kg (3.5-lb) weight loss. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 15 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm^3, and a platelet count of 320,000/mm^3. A peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the findings on this patient's peripheral blood smear?
content_preview: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 1-week history of fever and fatigue. During this period, she has also had decreased appetite and a 1.5-kg (3.5-lb) weight loss. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 15 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 320,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the findings on this patient's peripheral blood smear?
hint: The peripheral blood smear shows neutrophilia.
learning_objective: Recognize acute bacterial infection as a cause of neutrophilia.

answers.explanation_why: This patient has many nonspecific clinical features of acute infection, including fever, fatigue, decreased appetite, weight loss, tachycardia, lymphadenopathy, and leukocytosis. Her young age, in combination with the specific finding of cervical lymphadenopathy, raises suspicion for infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. However, peripheral blood smear findings for acute viral infections typically show lymphocytosis, not neutrophilia. Furthermore, a classic finding in infectious mononucleosis is atypical lymphocytes (i.e., reactive T cells with abundant cytoplasm), which are not seen here.

Burkitt lymphoma is a B-cell lymphoma most commonly seen in children and can cause localized lymphadenopathy. However, the characteristic histopathologic finding associated with this condition is the presence of tingible body macrophages scattered diffusely within a sheet of uniform neoplastic cells in a sample of the tumor, not neutrophilia on a peripheral blood smear. In addition, Burkitt lymphoma does not typically cause fever, fatigue, decreased appetite, or weight loss.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) may cause fever, fatigue, decreased appetite, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and leukocytosis, all of which are seen here. ALL is also most commonly seen in children (peak incidence of 2–5 years of age). However, the characteristic peripheral blood smear finding associated with ALL is an abundance of large, immature lymphocytes (i.e., lymphoblasts), not neutrophilia. In addition, this patient does not have other typical findings of ALL, including pallor, bleeding, bruising, bone pain, and hepatosplenomegaly.

This patient has many nonspecific clinical features of acute infection, including fever, fatigue, decreased appetite, weight loss, tachycardia, lymphadenopathy, and leukocytosis. The peripheral blood smear finding of neutrophilia raises suspicion for a bacterial etiology. In response to bacterial infection, neutrophils demarginate from the vascular endothelium and are released from the bone marrow. This results in an increased concentration of neutrophils in the blood (i.e., neutrophilia) as they migrate to sites of infection to clear bacteria via phagocytosis. The bone marrow also increases neutrophil production, which can result in the presence of immature predecessors, such as band cells, in the blood (i.e., left shift).

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) may cause fatigue, decreased appetite, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and leukocytosis, all of which are seen in this patient. However, the characteristic peripheral blood smear finding associated with AML is an abundance of immature myeloid precursors (i.e., myeloblasts), not neutrophilia. In addition, AML most commonly develops in older adults (peak incidence of 65 years of age) and often causes pallor, weakness, bleeding, and hepatosplenomegaly, none of which are seen here.

This patient has many nonspecific clinical features of acute infection, including fever, fatigue, decreased appetite, weight loss, tachycardia, lymphadenopathy, and leukocytosis. However, acute parasitic infections do not typically lead to neutrophilia, which would be seen on a peripheral blood smear; they are more commonly associated with eosinophilia.

images.title: Neutrophilia
images.description: Photomicrograph of a blood smear (Giemsa stain; high magnification)An increased number of mature neutrophils (green overlay) with segmented nuclei are present in this blood smear, indicating neutrophilia. These are surrounded by normal erythrocytes (examples indicated by red overlay) and thrombocytes (examples indicated by arrowheads).
