question_text: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician because of hoarseness of voice and a chronic cough for the past 2 months. He has a history of hypertension well controlled with lisinopril. He has smoked one and a half packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks 60 mL of whiskey every other day. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows left-sided cervical lymphadenopathy. Laryngoscopy shows an erythematous and edematous left posterior larynx; there is an exophytic mass arising from the left posterior true vocal cord. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician because of hoarseness of voice and a chronic cough for the past 2 months. He has a history of hypertension well controlled with lisinopril. He has smoked one and a half packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks 60 mL of whiskey every other day. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows left-sided cervical lymphadenopathy. Laryngoscopy shows an erythematous and edematous left posterior larynx; there is an exophytic mass arising from the left posterior true vocal cord. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Smoking and alcohol consumption are the most important risk factors for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma.

answers.explanation_why: Leukoplakia is a hyperkeratosis of the epithelium and mucous membranes of the oral cavity. It can present with hoarseness if it involves the larynx, and tobacco smoking and alcohol consumption are important risk factors. However, leukoplakia of the vocal cords manifests with persistent white plaques that cannot be scraped off on laryngoscopy, which is not seen here.

Laryngeal papillomatosis is a benign tumor of the laryngeal epithelium that manifests with hoarseness and an exophytic lesion on the vocal cord on laryngoscopy. However, laryngeal papillomatosis is more common in children and young adults and is caused by HPV infection (HPV type 6 and 11). Moreover, a biopsy of the lesion shows hyperplastic stratified squamous epithelium with a central fibrovascular core, which is not seen here.

images.title: Laryngeal papillomatosis
images.description: Laryngoscopy showing laryngeal papillomas, appearing as multiple raspberry-like swellings on vocal cords.

answers.explanation_why: Laryngeal adenocarcinoma is very rare and is only seen in 1–2% of cases of laryngeal carcinoma. The photomicrograph of the biopsy specimen of the lesion does not show malignant adenomatous changes.

Laryngeal amyloidosis is a localized form of amyloidosis, which can manifest with hoarseness, cough, and rarely lymphadenopathy. However, laryngoscopy typically shows a firm orange-yellow to gray epithelial nodule and a biopsy of the lesion shows an extracellular deposition and aggregation of amyloid, neither of which is seen here.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx is the most common type of laryngeal carcinoma and is usually located on the glottis or vocal cords. Squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx is most common in men 40–70 years of age. Affected individuals typically present with chronic hoarseness or change in voice and cervical lymphadenopathy, as seen here. Other possible clinical signs are dysphagia, dyspnea, and stridor. Laryngoscopy provides direct visualization of the lesion and typically reveals an irregular, nodular, or ulcerative lesion. Biopsy shows moderately differentiated clusters of squamous cells with lymphovascular invasion.

A vocal cord polyp is a benign lesion of the vocal cords. It can present with hoarseness, it is usually unilateral, and it is commonly associated with chronic irritation due to voice overuse (e.g., teachers, professional singers), smoking, or GERD. However, a vocal cord polyp is typically found in the middle to anterior one-third of the vocal fold (i.e., anterior larynx), unlike what is seen here. Moreover, this patient's unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy is not consistent with a polyp of the vocal cord.

images.title: Laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of a laryngeal tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)Sheet-like arrangement of the tumor cells can be seen (green overlay). The increased number of lymphocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay in zoom box) and desmoplasia in the surrounding stroma suggest inflammation.

question_text:
A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of a 4-day history of a painful rash over his legs. He has not had fevers, joint pain, shortness of breath, cough, chest pain, or abdominal pain. Two weeks ago, he was admitted to the hospital for community-acquired pneumonia and was treated with ceftriaxone and azithromycin. His medical history is remarkable for hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender, nonblanching palpable purpura over his lower legs. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count
12,200/mm^3

Neutrophils
68%

Lymphocytes
23%

Eosinophils
2%

Platelet count
250,000/mm^3

Serum

Na^+

135 mEq/L

K^+

3.7 mEq/L

Urea nitrogen
10 mg/dL

Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL

Cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (c-ANCA)
Negative

Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA)
Negative

Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of a 4-day history of a painful rash over his legs. He has not had fevers, joint pain, shortness of breath, cough, chest pain, or abdominal pain. Two weeks ago, he was admitted to the hospital for community-acquired pneumonia and was treated with ceftriaxone and azithromycin. His medical history is remarkable for hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender, nonblanching palpable purpura over his lower legs. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.1 g/dL Leukocyte count 12,200/mm3 Neutrophils 68% Lymphocytes 23% Eosinophils 2% Platelet count 250,000/mm3 Serum Na+ 135 mEq/L K+ 3.7 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 10 mg/dL Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL Cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (c-ANCA) Negative Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA) Negative Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with tender, symmetrical palpable purpura on the lower extremities that manifested several days after cephalosporin administration. He has no systemic symptoms or abnormal laboratory results, which suggests a specific type of small-vessel vasculitis.
learning_objective: Recognize drug-induced cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis (leukocytoclastic vasculitis).

answers.explanation_why: Cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis (CSVV), i.e., hypersensitivity vasculitis, is a non-ANCA-associated necrotizing vasculitis of small vessels caused by immune complex deposition that is limited to the skin, with no involvement of other organs. This condition can be idiopathic or triggered by certain drugs (e.g., cephalosporins, sulfasalazine), infections (e.g., HIV, HCV), or autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE). Diagnosis requires ruling out systemic vasculitis. A skin biopsy typically revealing leukocytoclastic vasculitis is needed to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment involves management of the underlying cause (e.g., discontinuation of causative drugs). Immunosuppressive therapy may be required depending on disease severity and chronicity.

IgA vasculitis is a type of non-ANCA-associated small-vessel vasculitis that manifests with symmetrical palpable purpura on the lower extremities. Factors contributing to the development of this condition include preceding infections and certain drugs, such as macrolides. However, IgA vasculitis mostly occurs in children and typically manifests with arthralgia, gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., colicky abdominal pain), and kidney involvement (e.g., hematuria, proteinuria), which are not seen here.

Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis is a type of non-ANCA-associated small-vessel vasculitis that manifests with palpable purpura. This condition is most commonly caused by cryoglobulinemia due to hepatitis C infection and typically involves other organs, resulting in systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, arthralgia, myalgia), glomerulonephritis, and/or polyneuropathy. This patient's condition is limited to the skin, making an alternative diagnosis is more likely.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is a small-vessel vasculitis that may manifest with purpura of the lower extremities and lower respiratory tract involvement. However, patients with GPA typically present with constitutional and ENT symptoms (e.g., chronic rhinitis, chronic otitis), renal involvement (e.g., elevated creatinine, hematuria), and ocular, and/or cardiac involvement. Moreover, laboratory studies in GPA show increased inflammatory markers and positive c-ANCA.

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA) is a small-vessel vasculitis that may manifest with palpable purpura. Patients with EGPA typically present with asthma attacks, tender nodules, mononeuritis multiplex, and gastrointestinal, cardiac (e.g., pericarditis), and/or renal involvement (e.g., elevated BUN and creatinine). Constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue, fever) are also common in EGPA. Moreover, blood tests typically show eosinophilia and are often positive for p-ANCA.

question_text: A 66-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of a painless, progressively growing lump on her neck. She has no difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, or dyspnea. Past medical history is unremarkable. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use other substances. She appears well. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 2-cm (0.8-in) nodule on the right side of her neck that moves with swallowing. Serum TSH concentration is 0.2 μU/mL. Ultrasound shows a 2.3-cm (0.91-in) hypoechoic mass in the right thyroid lobe. Thyroid scintigraphy reveals a nodule with decreased radiotracer uptake. Fine-needle aspiration cytology shows concentric lamellar calcifications, large oval nuclei with central clearing, and lymphocytic infiltration. Molecular genetic testing showed no BRAF mutations. Which of the following factors in this patient most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?
content_preview: A 66-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of a painless, progressively growing lump on her neck. She has no difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, or dyspnea. Past medical history is unremarkable. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use other substances. She appears well. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 2-cm (0.8-in) nodule on the right side of her neck that moves with swallowing. Serum TSH concentration is 0.2 μU/mL. Ultrasound shows a 2.3-cm (0.91-in) hypoechoic mass in the right thyroid lobe. Thyroid scintigraphy reveals a nodule with decreased radiotracer uptake. Fine-needle aspiration cytology shows concentric lamellar calcifications, large oval nuclei with central clearing, and lymphocytic infiltration. Molecular genetic testing showed no BRAF mutations. Which of the following factors in this patient most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?
hint: Concentric lamellar calcifications (psammoma bodies) and large oval nuclei with central clearing (Orphan Annie eyes nuclei) are typical features of papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC).
learning_objective: Recall the prognostic factors in thyroid cancer.

answers.explanation_why: Certain histopathological features, such as vascular infiltration, are associated with a poor prognosis in patients with thyroid cancer, but lymphocytic infiltration is associated with a lower recurrence rate and reduced mortality.

Certain histopathological features in thyroid cancer, such as vascular infiltration, are associated with a poor prognosis. However, psammoma bodies simply indicate dystrophic calcification and are a defining feature of PTC. Among all histological variants of thyroid cancer, PTC generally has the best prognosis.

The peak incidence of PTC is 30–50 years of age, and it generally has the best prognosis among all thyroid cancer variants. However, an older age at diagnosis is associated with a poor prognosis for papillary, follicular, and medullary thyroid cancers. The TNM staging system uses an age cutoff of ≥ 55 years to identify patients with a high risk of mortality from these cancers. Other factors indicating a poor prognosis include male sex, large tumor (i.e., > 4 cm), extrathyroidal growth, lymph node involvement with extranodal extension, multifocality, specific molecular characteristics (such as RAS and BRAF mutations), and certain histopathological features (e.g., tall cells, poor differentiation, and vascular infiltration).
PTC is more common in female than male individuals, but female individuals have a more favorable prognosis than male individuals.

Specific molecular characteristics, such as BRAF mutations, are associated with a higher risk of extrathyroidal extension, lymph node metastases, and distant metastases in PTC. The absence of BRAF mutations, on the other hand, is associated with a favorable prognosis.

question_text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a painless mass in her right axilla. She has noted progressive swelling in the area but has not had fever, night sweats, weight loss, or pruritus. She has no cough, dyspnea, or chest pain. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She emigrated from Peru five years ago. Family history is unremarkable. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears healthy. BMI is 22 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 121/64 mm Hg. Examination shows a firm, nontender, mobile 3-cm lymph node in the right axilla; there is no hepatosplenomegaly. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count and metabolic panel, are within normal limits. Excisional lymph node biopsy findings show hyaline vascular proliferation with regressed germinal centers and prominent capillaries. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a painless mass in her right axilla. She has noted progressive swelling in the area but has not had fever, night sweats, weight loss, or pruritus. She has no cough, dyspnea, or chest pain. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She emigrated from Peru five years ago. Family history is unremarkable. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears healthy. BMI is 22 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 121/64 mm Hg. Examination shows a firm, nontender, mobile 3-cm lymph node in the right axilla; there is no hepatosplenomegaly. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count and metabolic panel, are within normal limits. Excisional lymph node biopsy findings show hyaline vascular proliferation with regressed germinal centers and prominent capillaries. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This condition may involve a single region of lymph nodes (unicentric) or multiple regions of lymph nodes (multicentric). Multicentric disease is common in patients with HIV.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical presentation and diagnostic features of Castleman disease.

answers.explanation_why:
Castleman disease is a rare lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by localized, non-tender lymphadenopathy, most commonly in the mediastinum or axilla. The unicentric form is typically asymptomatic, with normal laboratory findings, and involves a single lymph node. Histopathology findings show a regressed (atrophic) germinal center surrounded by concentric layers of small lymphocytes (onion-skin appearance) and prominent capillary proliferation with hyalinized walls. The disease is benign but may require surgical excision for definitive treatment.

Multicentric Castleman disease manifests with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss) and hepatosplenomegaly and is more common in patients with HIV and HHV-8 coinfection.

Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic, inflammatory skin disorder of the apocrine glands that manifests with painful, recurrent nodules, abscesses, and sinus tracts in intertriginous areas (e.g., axilla). This patient has an isolated painless mass, making an alternative diagnosis more likely.

While tuberculous lymphadenitis can manifest with a firm, mobile lymph node in the axilla, patients typically also have constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fever, night sweats). Moreover, histopathology findings show caseating granulomas, rather than hyaline vascular proliferation with regressed germinal centers and prominent capillaries.

Hodgkin lymphoma typically manifests with painless lymphadenopathy, often in the cervical or mediastinal regions, as well as B symptoms, splenomegaly or hepatomegaly, and focal or generalized pruritus. While this patient has cervical lymphadenopathy, he does not have pruritus, B symptoms, or organomegaly. Moreover, histopathology findings show Reed-Sternberg cells (large cells with binuclear or bilobed nuclei with dark centers of chromatin and pale halos, which result in an owl-eye appearance), rather than hyaline vascular proliferation with regressed germinal centers.

Cat scratch disease (CSD) manifests with swollen, tender lymph nodes in the axilla. However, CSD follows exposure to an animal (most commonly a cat) scratch, bite, or saliva and is often accompanied by constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, myalgias). Additionally, histopathology findings in CSD show granulomatous inflammation with central stellate microabscesses, rather than hyaline vascular proliferation or regressed germinal centers.
